7375303102053764398.voice_to_text: in support of setting standards for your kid why don't we get ready together or talk about our strict as a child who grew up in a household where everybody considered my parents to be strict I have this happened to this conversation because I used to get picked on laughed at for how strict my parents were and obviously didn't care because I enjoyed the things that they like made us do or required us to do um but looking back now as a 29 year old I'm so thankful I did not think of it at the moment but i'mma talk to you guys about some of the things that my parents had us doing growing up and I grew up in a two parent black household my parents have been married for 35+ years I have an older brother younger sister and a middle child they had all of us doing the same so similar to what this creator had posted we were not allowed to watch TV during the week I distinctly remember us not being able to watch TV you did your homework you went outside you had extracurricular activities as we got older no TV and I'm a 90s baby I was born 95 my brother's born 93 my sister's born 98 so we all kinda group in the same era where we do not have access to all of this elaborate technology that kids have today so not only that but I don't know if you guys grew up with the jumpstart programs it was like a rabbit or some kind of an animal on top of these like workbooks for school the schools would sell or you know encourage parents to purchase for the summer vacation and every single year my parents purchased them for us we were required to do an activity out of the book every single day so we would not lose all that we had Learned during school year this is the funniest one y'all as a punishment I remember I think it was for my 10th birthday I got an attitude or something so if you believe it I would get in trouble for having smart mouth like that was hell in trouble so one of my punishments it was for my birthday I was not allowed to have a party I wasn't getting no presents no cake no nothing they were still gonna take me out to dinner because it was a family thing so they weren't gonna deprive the family of an Audi because of my attitude but I had to read the autobiography of George Washington Carver and then write a book report on it and that was my punishment for my birthday for being sassy and it took me all day to do that report and my mom was like nope tell me about the book write the report I need the click notes all that up whatever I need all of it the activities that my siblings that I participated in I did ballet and dance growing up I was also varsity cheerleader in high school and then went on to be part of the dance team our dance team went to New York and high school went to Broadway shows we took all types of like classically trained classes those are the things that I was involved in on top of playing the clarinet and the piano I played piano for 11 years I played clarinet for six years um my school district would have like district band region band all those things I was getting first year y'all like a complete music nerd my black siblings played soccer European football okay both of them played soccer both of them played travel soccer my brother made some type of elite youth team I wanna say middle school early early high school time and got invited to go play in Sweden for some type of a tournament for youth teams and he went my sister played travel ball and she also made ODP which is Olympic development so she was on those types of teams so much to the point where she was offered a full ride scholarship to play soccer women soccer at UNC Chapel Hill as a black girl so people that too my parents did not purchase cable so growing up I didn't have access like everyone's like oh I grew up watching at 1:06 in Parguta no me and my brother and sister did not like my parents were not buying cable so the only time we could actually watch these cable style TV shows for kids like Disney Channel etc so they all used to come on um regular TV Saturday mornings on ABC kids we were allowed to watch TV Friday evening afternoon so my favorite shows were Arthur and cyberspace and sometimes Dragon Tales I'll get watch that but even from those shows you're still learning something and then we would get up on Saturday morning and watch ABC kids watch all the Disney Channel cable shows just be in the know what's happening and then we'd have to go outside and play like it wasn't us sitting around scrolling doing nothing sitting on your butt then to top all that off I also think about um the education my parents gave us with like taking care of our bodies and our health and our fitness no they weren't the most perfect by any means but I look at like the way that I live my life now and the things that they instilled on us and I'm so appreciative because I work in fitness a lot of adults don't know how to eat healthy they don't know how to exercise they don't know how to do anything because again a standard wasn't set for them because they're parents gardens etcetera didn't have a standard for themselves the cycle continues so you see why it is important to set strict rules for your kids and teach them things they can use as a later adult we always had a vegetable for a meal a fruit or a vegetable and or both depending on if it was like a breakfast or something we were not sitting around eating a whole bunch of processed snacks you get a Debbie cake or something for lunch and that's it it wasn't just me sitting around snacking around eating all throughout the day especially on the weekend and the funniest part 2 we weren't allowed to drink like fruit juices sodas we could have 8 ounces of juice at dinner time and my sister used to literally drink that juice so hard mom was like once you're done with that you get water the rest of the night so like she used to have to take my sister's cup and put it in the middle of the table so she wouldn't drink all her juice and then not eat her dinner so her juice was like her treat after dinner but we'll be sipping real slow eating dinner cause it was like once you finish like 8 ounces that's it you're not getting any more going back to the Jump Start for kids summer booklet we had a couple babysitters growing up and my mom literally would tell them like make sure they do an assignment don't let them go outside and play until an assignment is done and our babysitters listen cause my mom was paying them and made us do these assignments and if you didn't do the assignment and do it with some thought and care when mama came home from work in the summertime you're gonna have to erase it and do it all over again right we were also if you're from Columbia South Carolina you know how really dope the um downtown library was once upon a time it's now kind of been taken over by people experiencing homelessness but that's beside the point we used to go to that library all the time and do the reading programs where you would get like free McDonald's or a free ice cream cone or something for reading a certain level the library also used to have storytelling and puppet shows we would go down there and pick out books um we did the accelerated reading in school where you would get certain points for reading different books you could get to purchase something from the stores like that was the generation that I grew up in and that stuff is so important and kids honestly and truly need all that again like if god blesses me to be a mother at some point in my life I'm going to raise my children in that same way because literally I have so many tools and skill sets and just like a knowledge of ways to be and exist as an adult that I wouldn't have had had my parents not push those experiences um and have these quote unquote trick rules like it's not strict kids need to be guided it's like a puppy you gotta train it right ugh but I love that I love that more more uh millennial babies tapping what was y'all's family's rules cause like it's insane to me i used to get picked on for that kind of stuff but like look at me now thank you mister and missus parker i'm a dad shout out to y'all

but like there's a there's a queer event here in Liverpool that happens once every month you have to pay to get in and everything so one would assume that most people that go there are in fact queer or at least part of the LGBT community in a way so when I was there with my friends I saw this guy that I thought was really cute okay he was he looked nerdy but then was dancing and had this confident vibe to him so I was immediately attracted to him and I I commented with my friend like oh that guy um that guy super hot super cute I'm into him and and to my surprise he said oh yeah yeah I know him I was here last time I spoke to him and we hanged up hung out for a bit and he was dancing in the stage and everything so I was like oh fantastic I have my way into the conversation so when that guy and my friend were speaking I kinda went to them and was like oh you two are friends and made conversation with with the guy and then like maybe maybe it was my mood or a drink or two but I was more confident than average for a night out so I said to the guy look you are cute can I have your number kinda thing right and she's like oh yeah yeah took my phone put his number you know gave me the phone back so I was like okay okay like things things are going well go grab a drink come back to the dance floor and then I'm I was dancing with him right um at a certain distance but I was dancing to him and then I tried to get closer to him to dance just with him and as I do that he kinda like steps back and I took that as a sign of like okay maybe he's just here to to kinda like vibe and have fun with his friends or whatever then he just comes to dance and not really to to meet people I guess um so I was like okay no worries still she's still hot still cute whatever I I'll just vibe um the next day I messaged the guy it's like oh like I never seen you before on on Gaytown cause like the the the queer event kinda happens in a venue that is a bit separate from the the local gay bars area so I said look I I've never seen you around do you usually go out you should tag along with us next time we go out and everything and he's like yeah man I I never go there I'm not I'm not gay I'm straight and I was like what the fuck I had references for my friend I I was like 99% sure he was by gay whatever right um and and I was like look just out of curiosity why do you go to that event um if you are straight and and he told me that he goes there because it's where he feels uh like he can be whatever he wants to be or dress how he wants to dress and and like dance how he wants to dance without I guess the pressures of straight culture or something I don't know like my friends said that oh maybe maybe he's like straight and going bi or he's starting his journey or whatever but in this cases I take people for their work so you know if he tells me he's straight he's straight and that's it until he tells me otherwise so it kinda like the conversation died down and I moved on but it was such a shame because it was like the day I got confident to kinda like go to someone and ask for their number and he knew my friend so and my friend had told me they had danced before in the stage on a the queerest event in Liverpool so I was like you know it's my short it's going to be a hit and then it wasn't so yeah it is what it is right but it's funny how even straight a girlfriend because he told me he was trying to get with the girls there so and funny enough the next month I saw him again and kind of laughed about the situation but um yeah that's it

7375282435342355754.voice_to_text: every single time I have surgery I start beating the shit out of everybody in my sight after I wake up okay story time because this is literally me so when I was 22 um I had my very first anesthesia or procedure thankfully I never needed it as a kid so I never knew how I did with anesthesia or anything so when I was 22 I flew to Mexico so I can get plastic surgery now I asked to be awake I asked for local anesthesia so local meaning that they only numb or put anesthesia in the area that they're going to be operating on so prior to working on me the doctor asked me how do you normally do with anesthesia and I'm like to be honest I don't know I've never had anesthesia so he's like okay that's fine you know whatever we'll just do local like you're fine so looking back on it I probably should have got general because even though I was under anesthesia they were working on my ears I got an autoplasty I was literally able to feel and smell everything I feel I was able to hear and smell everything cause they're working right on your ears like your hearing bones are right here so I was literally able to like hear the cutting hear the lasers I was able to smell my flesh burning off whatever anyway sometime during the surgery during the operation I start to feel everything going on right so like I guess anesthesia is wearing off I'm feeling everything and I'm quiet cause you know I'm like little shy girl like I don't wanna interrupt them while they're operating on me so that you know what i'mma tough it out right I know I'm not supposed to be feeling this but I mean I'm I'm not gonna say nothing like why am I gonna interrupt them I'm not gonna be rude right so you know I guess they end up seeing that I'm making faces cause they're working right above me so they're seeing like that I'm squinting and then I'm kinda like you know making faces and the doctor stops and he looks at me and he asks me in Spanish he's like does it hurt and I'm like yeah it actually really freaking hurts and then like his eyes widened the nurse's eyes widened and I can just see them like looking above me looking at each other like oh my god so he's like it's not supposed to happen like that's not supposed to hurt I'm sorry we'll put more whatever right I I'm like dude it's not a big deal what I mean it was a big deal cause it freaking hurt but like me being nice and whatever I was kinda like it's not a big deal like he has a fine right so anyway that was my experience with local anesthesia um fast forward like 2 3 years I'm now 24 and I have to get an endoscopy done so I get that done here in the US and prior to going into the procedure room um the nurse asked me the nurse was actually really rude but the nurse asked me she's like how do you normally do with anesthesia with like being put to sleep and I was like well I've never been put to sleep before but I've had local anesthesia and local anesthesia you know it's worn off on me before not sure if I needed more if it was just me like I don't know but this is what happens with local she proceeds to like cut me off and she's like I'm not talking about local anesthesia like I'm talking about general like have you ever been put to sleep and I was like okay ma'am like so whatever since you're talking about general no I've never been put to sleep right so she's like okay whatever so we get into the procedure room for that and I am telling everyone I'm like hey just to let you know I've never been put to sleep I'm a little nervous and they're like no you'll do fine like whatever it's okay and I was like okay sounds good right they reassured me so for those of you that don't know an endoscopy is when they stick a camera down your um down your your throat and into your stomach you know whatever they do all that so uh they have me laying on my side so that I'm like laying on this arm I'm laying on my side and they put like a block in my mouth so that way they have access to my throat so they put the block in my mouth they end up like I guess giving me the anesthesia I end up knocking out um then I'm like dead knocked out cold so anyway during the procedure I guess I thought it was a dream until they ended up confirming later on but I was dreaming that I had woke up and I'm up in the procedure room right and I'm like looking around and I'm like well this is uncomfortable so I start to grab the camera that's in my mouth and I tried pulling it out like I'm pulling out the camera and um the nurses were behind me cause I was laying on my side I was fighting them like I was pushing them cause they were trying to grab me back and tell me to calm down and I was like uh no so I'm pushing them back I'm fighting them I'm trying to pull the camera out of my mouth the doctor that's like doing the actual procedure that has the cameras like holding onto the camera for dear life and then I guess we have like a it was like a student doctor something with some more drugs and you know I ended up being fine and that's cause I got that good stuff let me tell you like I ended up seeing the report and what they gave me it was that good stuff so I don't know how the hell but anyway um yeah I end up waking in the recovery room everything is fine I ended up asking the nurse because I thought it was a dream like I said to end up asking the nurse I was like I felt like it was a big deal like I was really pushing the nurses like I got a hold of my camera was pulling it like I feel like it wasn't a big you know to me it wasn't a big deal so like I think I was just dreaming tell me why like a couple days a week later when I ended up getting a report of my endoscopy like my results I end up seeing like it was stated there that I was resisting 7375275232271060267.voice_to_text: I'm so glad I found this video because I switched seats with someone on an airplane once and it did not go well for me so a few years ago I took a Spirit Airlines flight to Vegas when I got to my seat the person sitting behind me asked if we could switch seats cause he wanted to sit next to his friend and I'm a nice guy so I said sure whatever we can do that but then about halfway through the flight he goes to use the bathroom comes back from the bathroom and an attendant follows him back she approaches him and asks in a very hush tone excuse me sir did you smoke in the bathroom and he says I hit my vape and she informs him that that's incredibly illegal to do and he's got to fill out a lot of paperwork mid flight and of course I'm giggling in front of him because that's such a dumb thing to get in trouble for the flight ends I got off the plane he gets off the plane he's got to talk to some US Marshals because he's in trouble but then I go on to have a good time in Vegas and I don't think about the situation until I have to go back to the airport when I return to the airport to leave Vegas my ticket won't scan immediately I take my ticket to the customer service lady to see what's going on and she says to my face that my ticket has been canceled because I smoked on the airplane and I immediately tell her no I did not smoke on the airplane and then I realize I switch seats with the guy who did smoke on the airplane he tells me there's nothing I can do I am banned from Spirit Airlines I need to find a new flight back to Vegas and reach out to spirit through their customer support email to try to get unbanned in the meantime I was stranded in Vegas for not one not two but three days while I was waiting for my new flight and the kicker spirit got back to me and said that there's nothing that they can do I am permanently banned from Spirit Airlines so the moral of the story don't switch seats with someone on an airplane cause you don't know how dumb they might be

like they were all in this giant friend group and they all have their first kid around the same time it turns out they all had boys and one of them was my older brother and so they all grew up together and then about five years later everybody had their second child once again all boys and then my brother was kind of sad cause he was like I want a sibling and my mom was like I don't want another child and my dad was like I want another child and so somehow they commenced her and so that's where I came in so growing up I was just surrounded by nothing but boys and it was just super fun and so when I was in well no when I was like around six months or so we all ended up going to the same daycare and one of the couple my parents were closest to um they put their child in daycare too and so he's around one years old and he can talk and everything and he literally like my mom would say no one could come near me he would be like my Sydney cause he couldn't say my name so that's what he called me and to this day like mainly my dad um he used to just yell that and like call me it was just like a nickname he gave me because of that they thought the situation was so cute and um I went to kindergarten with him so when I was younger I didn't understand or didn't realize like me and my brother were not going to go to the same class when I was in kindergarten so um I cried my eyes out on the first day of school and that same kid who is in daycare with me came and found me and he like cheered me up before he went to class and it was just really cute and um and then starting in seventh grade he was in eighth grade obviously cause he's a year older than me ever since then like he would thoroughly embarrass me anytime he saw me at school it was awful in the like funniest most embarrassing older brother way humanly possible well he just got married uh last month and it was so freaking embarrassing but I was walking I hadn't seen him in a couple years and I was like walking to get to my seat for the wedding and they were taking photos I thought they didn't see me or whatever and I was trying not to be seen and then all of a sudden of course they do exactly what they did in high school which was like thoroughly embarrassed me by like just screaming out my name like oh my god Sydney Sydney it was horrifically embarrassing I was like why are we still doing this and they did it again at the reception but yes 100 1,000,000% this is just the best thing to do is all I'm trying to say it honestly it's the best thing you can do your your child will forever have a best friend even if they go their separate ways like like I said we go years without talking and then we always find our way back to each other so yeah I think this is just so cute

will first of all if you do not follow Jen Jen Gomez she is freaking amazing she's funny she did 10 years in prison and she tells stories and like certain things I have been going down the rabbit hole of her page and her best friend tree pages her best friend trees page like they're so funny I absolutely love them so if you guys have not followed them go over to her page follow her support her find her friend they're both amazing so anyway I have noticed so when you're in prison and you don't have money on the books when you don't have somebody from the outside putting money on your phone money on your books whatever the case may be you're considered indigent so when you are indigent and you can't buy soap you can't buy food you can't buy deodorant you can't buy any of that they give you Bob Barker soap Bob Barker toothbrush Bob Barker everything y'all from your shoes to your toothpaste to your toothbrush to the deodorant that doesn't freaking work and I have noticed that the ones who are indigent and use the Bob Barker soap is when that fishy smell is the worst you can walk in that shower room and be like oh my god what the hell is going on and who the fuck what the fuck kind of fish market opened up in here okay because it's freaking bad it's horrific I don't think I've ever smelled a smell that comes close to that okay and I've I've just noticed that when people are indigent and still rank who are still dirty ass bitches and still smell like fish but in my experience which you know everybody's experience in prison is a little bit different like you still get people that stink bad really freaking bad um but because the other thing that I've noticed is if you don't have good hygiene on the outs nine out of 10 times you're not gonna have good hygiene when you come in um my their shower as crazy as that sounds times were so different back then um but anyway so I just wanted to stitch her video because she's so right it is a real thing and you really get the smell and see 7374964747508256043.voice_to_text: who was the elementary school teacher who had beef with you for no reason I have two teachers that hated me for no reason um but we're only gonna focus on one because the other because one of them was technically when I was in sixth grade so technically I would have been in middle school but anyway I was in the third grade and I had this teacher we'll call her Miss C she wasn't even actually the teacher she was the assistant teacher but she would find every little thing to pick on me about it's like she was constantly just waiting for me to do something and just like just point at and be like that's bad sometimes I would be getting bullied and she would do nothing about it and when I would tell her about it she would take the bully side every time but this story sticks out the most I was always raised to say thank you ma'am yes ma'am no sir yes sir you know being a polite kid and one day we're doing math and the actual teacher of this class said Selah I need you to do such and such so how do I respond I say yes ma'am should be nothing wrong with that right what could possibly go wrong after I did what I was told to do the assistant teacher Miss C pulled me aside and she gets up in my face and she goes do you think you're better than everyone and I'm like what and she goes you're being a little brown noser  Now I didn't know what that meant I was in the third grade the only thing in my head that I could think of was  No I'm white you're you're the one with the brown nose thankfully I didn't say that out loud but then she started going on and on and on and berating me for saying yes ma’am  and how I was trying to be a Miss Goody two shoes and a brown noser  and trying to be better than everyone else and if I ever did that again that I wouldn't be allowed to have recess for the week so I stopped saying yes ma’am  because I'm scared and then my mom would get upset she's like excuse me it's yes ma'am and I was a kid so I didn't know what to do anymore but yeah that just makes me so incredibly mad

7374955660749835562.voice_to_text: all in all she gave that message to let us all know that she's classist that's all it is it wasn't about the kids it's not about the fact that she's being protective no she's using that as a means to let us know that she's been to school long enough where she chose the right career that pays her well enough to be able to walk into a grocery store make a mess out of the aisles use the shopping cart put her stuff in it take it to the car and then leave that shopping cart in the parking spot next to her because we're not gonna even act like she goes to the bay outside to put the cart back because that's poor people things that's things that peasants get paid pennies to do why am I a doctor gonna go out of my way to help anybody else I already do that as a living god forbid I actually just go ahead and go the extra mile and help somebody else make their job just a little bit easier by being responsible no I don't think so I think I'm just gonna go ahead and let them deal with it because that's what they get paid to do they chose that job to be miserable so I'm just gonna contribute to that mess that's what this is giving but props to you for thinking you were actually gonna make a point by using your kids that's very poor poor character to try and hide behind your children as a reason as to why you're irresponsible as an adult but I digress here we are you throw that f at us I grabbed it and gave it back to you because I am responsible have the day you deserve

7374955000889429290.voice_to_text: it is absolutely culty I totally agree with you and when I was in prison the cult madness spread to the federal prison yeah story time guys this was crazy so in 2,017 Trump had just become president there were rumors going all around the prison that Trump was gonna close the camps and we were all gonna go home when in fact the guy Trump put in charge for um drugs and substances he had just changed what Obama had done where Obama was letting non violent first time drug offenders you know get two points off you know in their point system this guy Trump's guy turned it around so that drug dealers were getting the max we were having bus loads of first time drug offenders you know 10 years mandatory minimums they were showing up in bus loads but these women who had years to go you know they wanted to hold on to that little bit of hope that Trump's gonna close the camps they would have prayer circles every night praying for this man even though it was right in front of their face you know that people were getting sentenced way more harshly the cops made this worse and they would throw few on the fire and you know say things to make inmates believe it even more and they thought it was funny this nonsense finally hit the fan and a woman who had only been there a couple months at the beginning of a five year bid who was absolutely desperate to go home her husband basically told her if she doesn't get her appeal to go through within a year he was gonna leave her she was not emotionally okay she convinced herself that the camps were closing on a particular date she called her family told them to get her a plane ticket she packed her bags and the staff knew this they had been monitoring this entire situation and they allowed it to get to this point she tries to leave and they stop her at the door and haul her off to the show they have a town hall meeting where everybody gets together and they have an announcement and they told us Trump is not closing the camps if you try to leave before your release date before you are allowed to you will get another charge desperate people tend to join cults and there are so many desperate Americans right now like it's no wonder this this cult took hold you can read about all this craziness and more in my upcoming book no justice just us um the website is up the Linktree is in my bio

7374840846937607466.voice_to_text: am I the 🍑🕳️ for telling my wife to stop crying at Home Depot look I was eight months into a relationship with my first boyfriend when I also had my first ever breakdown in a Home Depot okay so picture this I was 17 I was visiting my high school best friend in this town he moved away to called Dundas which is close to Hamilton Ontario my parents thought I was just there to visit him but little did they know my boyfriend lived up in Toronto and this was the closest my broke 🍑 could stay in order to go see him so the week started out normal I take the train up to Hamilton I meet my best friend we take my bags back to his parents house and then we both head downtown to take the go train to Toronto I was gonna see my boyfriend he was gonna see some girl I guess but his parents thought we were off exploring Hamilton for the day so we had like 8 hours to get to Toronto do what we had to do get back and meet his parents before they needed us and the visit went really well he met me downtown at Union Station we went our separate ways from bestie and we enjoyed our morning and the rest of our afternoon in his mom's apartment doing what lovers do if you will I made my way back to bestie we get back to Hamilton on time and his parents pick us up downtown so we head off to do some errands we were gonna help his parents with the next day first stop was Home Depot see on the way back to Hamilton I had texted a friend of ours let him know I was a man now and detailed everything that we did I didn't think anything of it but apparently our messy mutual couldn't keep his thoughts to himself and texted my boyfriend congratulating the both of us on being de flowered now my boyfriend never told me this before but apparently when it came to that sort of thing he was a very private person I thought it was okay to text a mutual friend of ours but I guess that was a fatal error he broke up with me right there in the Home Depot through text message and I tried to text him back to plead my case but I was already blocked cue the breakdown I fell out on some bags of soil and the tears started flowing immediately my bestie god love him noticed and dragged his parents to another aisle pretending to look for something so they wouldn't notice themselves and there I was sobbing and hyperventilating in a pile of dirt while Bleeding Love by Leona Lewis was blasting insanely loud from the store speakers and from around the corner comes bestie to get me back together before mom and dad came back apparently he sent them to get something on the other side of the store so he had time to come back and help me shake off whatever this was so he's got his hands on my shoulders looking me dead in the eyes trying to calm me down while every employee and middle aged father walks by giving me judgy 🍑 eyes as if most of their relationships probably weren't on the brink too 🍑🕳️s  but eventually I calmed down enough to tell him what happened he got me to pull it together by promising I could cry in his room later so we got it together before they came back we checked out and went on about our day full meltdown did happen later but I say all this to say 🪛 that man let your wife cry in Home Depot sometimes we need it okay 🐩

7374839620657319211.voice_to_text: give me the tea what's the drama what's happening in your life I wanna know so this is some old tea but it's still pretty strong so back in the 1930s my great grandfather who was my mother's mother's father became a self made millionaire and he had a wife and a son and a daughter so the daughter was my grandmother  and his wife and his son unfortunately I wanna say this would have been in the 1950s sometime his wife and his son died within six months of each other of cancer it was a blood cancer that runs in our family so the grief from that put him in a wheelchair now he was otherwise a really healthy person but he all the grief and all the stress from losing his like 20 something year old son and his wife just went straight to his back and he couldn't walk for like I wanna say at least a few months if not if not a year and during that time he met a woman who was 20 years younger than he was so he was born in 1895 so in the 1950s he would have been in probably his 50s or or close to 60 at this time so this woman was 20+ years his junior and she also knew that he was Catholic cause my family is French Canadian this was my Pépère so he also because he was Catholic and he was very Catholic he did not believe in divorce and she knew that so this woman took a look at him and said he's in a wheelchair he's a multi millionaire he's already close to 60 if I marry him he won't divorce me and I'm gonna get his money and I'm gonna be able to go to these parties in Europe I'm gonna be able to go yachting I'm gonna be able to buy all these furs and stoles and just live it up and have the life I've always felt I deserved well that did not work out so well for her because my great grandfather got out of that wheelchair and continue to live a rather healthy and happy life So he also never lived in a mansion or anything like that he lived in a small house in either Lewiston or Auburn Maine but it was you know one of the the small houses you would have seen that were built they were all built in the I think 50s  and they it was it was like a it was like a one or two bedroom house like really very humble and he walked everyday and he lived a rather simple life so the yachts and the parties in Europe and all the stuff that she was wanting never happened so she became a very angry bitter person and she hated my grandmother she hated the majority of my family  I remember when I was a kid she gave me a gift of used toothbrushes for my birthday she gave my sister a set of towels once because she had forgotten about my sister's birthday  and was like oh well I'll give her these and it was it was a set of towels she gotten from like JC Penney or something there was one of the cousins that she she did spoil rotten  and but the rest of us were and she so the biggest revenge that basically our family could have had upon her was the fact that my great grandfather lived to be 101 and at the time of his passing she was not physically well enough to do any of the things that she had planned to do with his money the parties in Europe she was in her 80s at this point you know so she ended up within I believe I wanna say it was within eight months of his passing she was in basically in hospice care so she only outlived him by a few years really almost nothing now unfortunately she did have the wherewithal to liquidate his entire estate and send it off to her family with the exception of a handful of small items so but there is a moral to that story which is  if you're gonna marry somebody for material things you better be sure that they're a material person because my Pépère was not He was a man of integrity and a man of humility and  she did not get the life she wanted and she died miserable about it

7374825384560332075.voice_to_text: tell me something a job has taught you that you will never ever forget no matter what so I'm an artist and right out of college uh for my degree in studio art I started working at a like metalsmithing factory and I became a stonesetter by trade um because that was the only thing in my area that was like art adjacent but was still like a big kid job so my mentor at that job who taught me everything I know about stone setting she had been working there for about 26 years and not a day went by that she didn't like talk about how much she was looking forward to retiring and she had a lot of health problems regarding that job because it was like you know sitting at a bench stone setting for nine hours a day um sometimes more than that so that's like really hard on your body and she'd been doing that for 26 years so she was set to retire in June of 2020 and in December of 2019 the factory shut down for like three days for Christmas break or whatever and I get a call from my other co worker that my mentor had passed away and I really I can't get over the fact how disappointing it was knowing that she didn't even get to enjoy the retirement she was so looking forward to she was just six months out from retiring um when she passed away so that really taught me to not sell my soul for a job for benefits for whatever to line somebody else's pockets um just to gain retirement because you don't know what life has in store for you and you might not be able to even enjoy your retirement

7374095608052862250.voice_to_text: okay story time so when I was kid I lived in Johnson City Tennessee anyway my mom worked at a church there in Johnson City and one time they decided that they wanted to take all the kids in the church on an overnight field trip to Ripley's Aquarium in Gatlinburg and when you book this trip you get to sleep in the aquarium all through the night and they have this tunnel where like you you're under the water and you get to just observe everything and so that's where you sleep in the aquarium super cool experience I don't know if they still do it but if they do you really need to check it out it's awesome so we're all getting ready to go to sleep and of course the adults are trying to wrangle like 30 kids to get them calm down I mean we're sleeping in an aquarium so we're really excited but finally we all got calmed down enough and we're all getting ready to go to sleep and we've been laying there for about an hour and suddenly we hear the squeaking sound we're like what is this squeaking sound it like like against the glass and so finally we look and we see that it was a stingray that had um a fish like this up against the glass because it was hungry it needed a midnight snack and if I'm not mistaken I don't know what the fish is actually called but it's the one that looks like Dory that's the fish that it had trapped and was going to eat and so we sat there forever watching some of us like oh no please don't eat the fish we’re little kids um some of us like yes eat the fish let's go let's go and I believe that in the end the stingray won so yeah I've experienced that very thing before the things that happen on a church trip man

7373619663734918433.voice_to_text: Give me the tea. What's the drama? What's happening in your life? I wanna know. So I'm a holiday baby, meaning? I didn't know my father growing up and he didn't know I existed. I grew up with a lesbian mum who was very honest with me about everything. Obviously, I knew her point of view. I knew why she didn't tell him. Growing up, I never really questioned it. Um, I had no interest in the subject, really, which I got a lot of shit for, especially from adults. Things changed around the time that I was 24 (23*) years old. I was at uni, I was finishing up my degree, and I had to do a final project, um, for my theatre degree. And I thought, what's better time than now? I've got some funds, um, I can make it into story. And I guess that was my way of coping with it. So when I was 24, I went to find him. I had my filmmaker friend with me, and as I was there, I created an online performance, I called it. So I was vlogging, I was blogging, I was live streaming, and people were watching me live try and find my father. So not only did I find my father, I was being graded as I was in the process of doing so. Even though things didn't work out well, I still have a lot to look back on. I've got all that material. Um, I eventually made it into a stage show. Um, this was years ago. I'm 31 now. Um, I think I was 24 back then. I did see my father again on another trip after that. Um, I no longer speak to him. We don't speak. He doesn't speak to me. Um, neither does the family over there. And, uh. Yeah, that's how things are. Even if I wanted a different outcome, I don't regret it.

7373535530581167406.voice_to_text: I'll tell you guys a funny story when I was consulting for a company called hawkers back in the day in Los Angeles they were throwing a Coachella party that cost $60,000 for three days for just the house we also booked Tyga Post Malone and Rae Sremmurd Tiger got paid like $10,000 the time to perform but the house was like popping off every celebrity was there and Tiger when he arrived said he wants an extra $5,000 to throw out while he plays the song Rack City or he's not gonna perform I went and told uh the boss of hawkers and he said no problem here's 5K gave it to a tiger and then I was running around the party there's a bunch of different houses at the compound we were staying in and um I remember later in the evening some girl walked in some influencer chick walked into the room I was in and was like holding a bunch of cash and we're just like dumbfounded and I was like what happened she was like Tiger started performing and throwing out like hundred dollar bills for Rack City and you know how LA is no one bent over to pick it up cause no one to seem like they don't have money or whatever but she was like on her hands and knees picking money up and she ended up having like 900 bucks and it reminds me of this video so um yeah fun story time for you guys enjoy

7373511525551656222.voice_to_text: Give me the tea. What's the drama? Absolutely. So my parents got separated in November of 2021. And at that point, my mom went and kind of did her own thing, lived with us for a while, then ended up moving out. But me and my dad were in my house like normal. And at one point, my dad looked at me and said, hey, would you mind if I started dating? And I go, no, that wouldn't bother me at all. I want you to be happy. As one would. So he started dating, and the trend was concerning. The trend was half is his age, so it was okay. For a little while. He was kind of dating, playing around. And then I started coming home to specifically Korean women in my house, and different ones every couple weeks. So he had this one girlfriend for a while. She was here illegally. 37, he's 55 at this point, and had two kids. And within six months of them dating, he's like, we're getting married. And I'm like, okay, probably not. You probably shouldn't do that. And by around January, he's like, okay, I don't think she's attracted to me. And, like, maybe she's using you for your money, for citizenship, so. And stuff with that lady. I go on a weekend trip, come back, he goes, we broke up, but I have a new girlfriend now. What do you mean? So I kind of don't see her. Don't Know who she is. For a while, I'm kind of taken aback by the whole situation. Obviously a little uncomfortable. Um, but this one's, like, looks a lot younger, and I'm like, okay, so this is, like, a year, a little over a year ago. January, February. And the months go on. She comes over a couple times, but he's spending weekends away in, like, Orange County, which is, like, two hours away. And eventually, summer comes around, I graduate high school, and things are getting suspicious. And I talked to my mom, who has a boyfriend at this point, and he's cool or cool. And I talked to my mom, like, I'm worried that he's thinking about getting married again, because obviously, it happened really quick the last time. And she's like, I'm suspicious. They already are. I go, oh, without telling me? Without telling his only child. And so I look through his office, I snoop through his office, and I find, like, a documents, like, in a folder from, like, some department. And first thing I see is, oh, she's 23. She is five years older than me. He's 56, she's 23, and they're married.

7373461971481529642.voice_to_text: I want you to think back to 2012 and 2013 I'm avoiding my homework and I wanted to talk about where I was in 2012 because it's kind of mind boggling to think about this like 12 year cycle that the astrology girlies are talking about because wow in 2012 I had graduated from college in 2010 it took me until mid 2012 early 2012 to be able to move out on my own uh I had finally gotten a job in early 2011 uh but I had still been living with my mom um and I finally got up the courage to leave and to finally be like no I am starting out on my own and again my mother and I were very enmeshed so it was like a big deal that I was leaving but I digress anyway 2012 March of 2012 I am turning 24 um and I moved to this tiny little apartment in East Boston and you guys it was so weird and like kind of it was definitely like shouldn't have been an apartment I was getting ripped off but it was fine uh I lived there from March and April and in June of that year I remember I went to go visit my friend Tracy who lives out on the West Coast who lives in LA and I had never been to LA so I went and I flew out to visit Tracy at the beginning of June so exactly 12 years ago to like right now I and when I came back I had bed bugs and because I knew that this place this apartment that I lived in was like for sure the reason why I had bed bugs I was just like I gotta move I gotta go like if you've not had bed bugs count yourself lucky because it is one of the most traumatizing ridiculous things that I have ever experienced I still have feelings um anyway my landlord was horrible and because the because he was like well you probably brought them back from your trip and I was like mmm honey no like I the this is probably just been building up I don't know whatever it was a mess he refused to pay for the extermination so I had to pay out of pocket to get somebody to come in and do like the heat treatment because it's the only thing that you can do to get bed bugs out I don't know it was insane um I was miserable that was the time I first started taking any kind of anti anxiety medication because I was a wreck so that was in June of 2012 I immediately moved out of that apartment and moved back in with my mother then had to kind of commute back and forth into Boston for work from like suburbs of Boston where my mom was living at the time and it was just miserable finally in September of 2012 my best friend from college Brian had an open room in his apartment in Cambridge Somerville area and I was like sure like I'm gonna move in so I moved into this teeny tiny room but I was so happy because I was away from my mom I was on my own again sort of even though I had roommates like I just felt like okay I can breathe again and then October is when I met my ex and we were together for almost nine years so like the trajectory of 2012 being summer trip to California bed bugs after like leaving home and having my own apartment and then going into this new complete new phase of life where I was in a couple for the first time in my life like the things that have happened since then the domino effect of that moment in time from June of 2012 is mind blowing to me and I just can feel like I feel like we're at that time again like I am such a different person than I was in 2012 and I think it's interesting that I'm turning I turned 36 this year because it's the completion of three 12 year cycles right uh I don't know I just it really got me thinking and excited for this like next 12 year cycle because I really do in my heart believe that like this year for me is that catalyst for this next 12 year cycle and looking back at what the catalyst was for that last 12 year cycle it's just it's so interesting so I don't know I rambled a lot but again I'm avoiding my homework so here we are

Okay, so I was, like, in first or second grade, I think, when this happened. And I was out at recess at school, and I was crying about something, cause I think some, like, girls in the class were, like, being mean to me or teasing me about something. And I was, like, super embarrassed to be crying at school. So instead of just being like, oh, I'm crying cause some kids are mean to me, I went and told them that I was crying because my dad was in a horrible car crash the night before and broke all the bones in his body. Because, you know, that makes sense. So they were like, oh, my god, I'm so sorry. Like, I hope he's okay. And I was like, yeah, I'm just, like, really upset about it, you know? So then, like, fast forward to, like, later that night. I'm at home with my parents, and I'm sitting in our living room. My dad, who's obviously fine, is, like, doing the laundry, like, ironing or whatever. My mom sitting in the living room with us, and our phone rings. And so my mom goes, Answers the phone, like, whatever. I'm just sitting there watching TV, and I just hear her go, like, hey, what's going on? And no, no, everything's fine. You heard what? And I'm, like, looking over at her some, like, oh, god. Like, am I about to get in trouble? And I hear this. No, Jordan's fine. He's standing here doing the laundry right now. And then I'm like, okay, this. It's happening. Like, we found out. So I'm, like, slinking slowly off the couch to, like, be as discreet as possible before I go, like, run upstairs to my room. And my mom just, like, looks over at me, and she's like, she said what? And so I'm like, okay, we're done here. And she's like, no, everything's fine. I'll talk to you later. So she hangs up. 7372704290986642706.voice_to_text: okay story time so my Year 10 formal was the night before one of my dance concerts my end of year dance concerts so interview dance concerts usually go for about three hours it's pretty full on that particular particular year I had been in I think it was nine dances there was lots of running back and forth having to get quick change and be on stage to do a different dance after the the following dance so it was it was a lot plus at that particular point that was the first year that I'd become a dance teacher so I wasn't just having to worry about my dances but my classes that I was teaching I also had to worry about them so going back to the night before it was my year 10 formal so went to the formal was fun but everyone knows in Australia that the after party is the actual Celebration so I hate it went to a friend's house we were staying at a friend's house and we started drinking at his place and then we'd walked to a house party which was probably about like a 30 minute walk from where we were staying you know back in the back in the fuckin uh 90s where you just walked everywhere so we start drinking before we walk to this party then we went to the party we were there for hours and hours we didn't get back to my friend's place until the early hours of the morning and when we got back we didn't sleep we were there just laying around chatting and you know not really worried about going to sleep so I think I went to bed at like 4:30 5 o'clock in the morning and I had to be up and back home at seven to do my dance concert I remember I remember being on stage before the first dance started and having people say oh you know I was really was really stressed out last night I couldn't sleep I was like had so much adrenaline because you know first dance concert I'm just like I stopped drinking at 4 o'clock in the morning and I'm still here so yeah I definitely think that my generation is different because I went I the whole day was fine I got through the entire dance concert and I really wasn't tired I think I was on that the adrenaline was pumping that hard that I just was like I can do this what like I done it so many times before lack of sleep and then just getting up and keeping on going I remember when I was 16 I had like four jobs and I was going to school so to me this one day of getting drunk the night before and having to get up on stage and dance for the next three hours was nothing so yeah I think our generations built differently

7372636277117603118.video_description: #stitch with @Rach Sullivan She’s almost 8 now & I could tell stories about her intuition & experiences for days🥹✨  #storytime #intuition #spiritguide #creepy #storytelling #momsoftiktok #babiesoftiktok
7372636277117603118.voice_to_text: When I was pregnant with my daughter, I would have very vivid dreams of my grandfather, who I never met. It was my mom's dad, and he had died when she was eleven. I'd have these very, very vivid dreams of him throughout my entire pregnancy. Fast forward to when that baby, my daughter, was 18 months old. We would get notifications like this from the rocking chair moving in her room around one a m. And one day it happened like three times in a row. And we would always watch the monitor and never felt evil. None of, like, my mom intuition was going off. There were no red flags. It was always just this subtle little movement in the rocking chair. But she would sit up in her crib and she would look over at the rocking chair. And sometimes she would wave, or sometimes she'd have, like, a little giggle. And then she would lay back down and go to sleep. One night she wakes up and we noticed that she wakes up. She sits up very peacefully, and she grabs her blanket. She's like, almost playing peekaboo. And the rocking chairs moving. And she's looking at the rocking chair, and out of nowhere she just starts singing Happy Birthday and, like, clapping her hands and singing Happy Birthday. The next day, I double checked, and it was my grandfather's birthday two days later. So I was sure that it was him. And it's still kind Of freaks me out, but it's also kind of cool.

7372562439772081454.voice_to_text: so to give some context and to cut a very long story short um the reason I was so excited to come back to work is because number one my coworkers are quite literally my second family I spend 40 hours a week with them every single week and I love getting to see them the second reason is because three weeks prior on May 4th I had had a full tonic seizure at work I collapsed to the floor I stopped breathing my lips were turning blue and I was also frothing at the mouth thankfully one of my co workers is was a nurse for 20 years and she came running and helped me get on my side and help get me to where I needed to be I don't remember any of this of course and that's fine while that was happening one of my other co workers timed the seizure seizure and then one of my other managers called 9 1 1 and if not for them I would literally be dead so I am very thankful to them um and the coworker that time the seizure came with me to the hospital um and I'm very thankful for all of them and I just I love getting to see them they are my second second family my second home and yeah they're my people and if you don't feel the same way about your work that is okay but I love my work and nobody can take that from me

7372562397237906734.voice_to_text: it's kinda sad that uh I bought this at an estate sale today my great grandfather was a rag and bone man a junk dealer Packrat or in modern terms a hoarder so when he passed away we had to go through their house and you know find important things and things we wanted to keep and it was a lot they had a lot of stuff every room was filled basically to the ceiling they had a stack of like 150 bicycles out in the yard it was it was a lot it was really cool to go through but in one room there were these boxes of old photographs old vintage black and white photographs and when my grandfather was going through them looking at these pictures his reaction was well now who the fuck are these people we're not related to them we have no idea who they are but at some point someone was either throwing these pictures away selling them at yard sales estate sales and my grandparents my great grandparents could not say no they saw these pictures and were like well they they can't go in the trash so instead they went in a box in their house and were really well preserved so now my grandfather has all these old photos and he's really into like history and genealogy so he's he's been trying to link these photos back up with families to return them to and it's been almost impossible so now they’re our family

7372326965929430318.voice_to_text: Girl, where do I start? I had this relationship for about two years, give or take. And me and god was tussling the entire relationship, like, from start to finish. Like, god was telling me, bitch, you need to stop fucking with this motherfucker. And I just didn't listen. And of course, I can't blame anybody but myself. Accountability is key. But anyways, I had this relationship where shit was rocky from the beginning. And I'm talking about things that just didn't make sense. Like, this person, I'm responding, me getting upset, and then just, like, constantly trying to turn it on me phone, constantly on D&D when. When we were together, like, just a lot of weird shit. And also, they didn't post me on social media. Should. A big, big red flag right there. Person cheated on me right around my birthday, went on a whole trip with somebody else. Like, god really was beating my ass in this relationship, I swear to you. So after we broke up, we took about 4 months without talking. Like, I went no contact completely. And, you know, I fell into my temptations of wanting to be toxic. So, of course, I fell in my. Meanwhile, they never stopped hitting me up. I fell into their trap for the last time, and we started talking. Months later, we ended up going on a trip together. Mind you, we were with my family. Like, my family to them. Like, we was broken. Up, which we was. But then I popped up to this family vacation with this motherfucker, and everybody was like, okay, we gonna mind our business. They ain't question me or nothing. One thing about my family is they always support me. And that's. That's a toxic trait of this, because sometimes just don't support me, you gotta slap me upside my head. But besides that. So we went on this trip together, and, you know, we were sleeping in the same bed, in the same room, whatever. And this said person, this was around when monkey pox was out. And at the time, the amount of knowledge we had was that it was a sexually transmitted thing. You know, that disease that came from monkeys that they get. You get blisters and it's itchy or whatever. Yeah, well, towards the end of the relationship, this girl was getting, like, blistered things, and she kept saying that it was itchy. I thought it was mosquito bites. Like, I didn't believe in that. She. She couldn't sleep, like, the last night cause she's like, oh, my god, I have, uh, monkey pox. And I'm like, girl, no, you don't. Go to hell. And it's like, she was so mad that I didn't believe her. But it's like, girl, I've been sleeping in the same bed as you every day, and I don't have shit. What the fuck is wrong with you? Those are mosquito bites. Fast forward when we land in New York, this girl goes to get tested. Was it not monkey pox? Like when I tell you, when I read that text, my jaw dropped. That was God's way. 7372285436766522670.voice_to_text: why would you wanna induce a woman who's going into natural labour on her own I was 7 cm into my home birth when my midwife said you have two hours to have that baby or you're going to the hospital so I asked my midwife what is it that the hospital's gonna be able to do for me that you can't do for me here at home she said give you Pitocin but I don't want potosa that's why I hired you and I had already had a successful birth with this midwife but come to think about it she did this two hour thing when I had my son and I was only 2 cm dilated and I ended up having him within the two hours so I was pretty confident that that was gonna happen this time but she made me go to the hospital she said she didn't want me to get an infection and have a C section soon as I got to the hospital they offered me a C section I rejected the C section and the Pitocin and I gave birth naturally

7372278668816665899.voice_to_text: so I have a funny version of this core memory back in middle school, I had relaxed hair it was a little past shoulder length it wasn't that long but it had some ✨swang✨ to it and one day in 8th grade I was talking to this girl (this was a Black girl, for the record) and I said something about my hair and she says something like “well we don’t know how many horses had to 💀 to get that hair” and I said to her, “girl, this is my hair, what are you saying?” and she says, “no it's not” and so then she calls this other girl over and she points at me and she's like “look at her hair! look at her hair! that’s fake right?” and the other girl’s like, “no that's not fake, that’s her real hair” so then the first girl's like, “well why is it so shiny then?” and then the other girl says “well that's what happens when you take care of it!”

7372265123081194785.voice_to_text: What did you do growing up poor? That would never make sense to rich kids. Found a crack house. Well, that's what we called it, eh? I think they call it bandos nowadays, but it's basically a house where drug users go to do drug using stuff. And we cleaned out so that we had somewhere to chill. Listen, before you judge, I grew up in Cheetah Mill, right? And when I was a teenager, we didn't have money and we didn't have smartphones. We just went to chill. It was raining really bad. We found an abandoned house, we thought, let's go in, see what's happening. And it went pretty silent, let me tell you. Honestly, it was an absolute health and safety hazard. Like now, as an adult and a parent, I just think, why? Why? There was used needles everywhere. There was quite possibly human feces. There was all sorts. There was all sorts. Those places that the rappers rap about nowadays. Damn. We kept it classy though. We put our little bit of pocket money together that we had. We went to the pound shop, we bought brushes, we bought bags, we bought cleaning stuff and we made that crack house into a homely crack house. Would we come back the next day to more needles? Yes, we would. Would we clean it back up? Yes, we would. And this is why I need counselling

7371840387821882666.voice_to_text: And be like, I don't like women who wear makeup. Why do you keep approaching them then? Okay, story time. Let's talk about it. So when I was younger, I used to wear the big 25 millimeter lashes, no shade. To my girlies that do. They're just not for me anymore. But when I was younger, I went all out. I'm talking about big 25 millimeter lashes, 30 inch buzz down my hair. Used to be to my ass. I didn't did every color you can think of. Honey blonde, 6 13. I had red hair, green hair, blue hair. Does not matter. Now, this story in particular, I was working at Walmart. I had 6 13 braids. And honey blonde braids out. Insert a picture if I could find. Okay. So I come to work, I'm not thinking nothing about it. And there's a guy that works there. And the stocking area. He approaches me. He telling me how he thinks I'm pretty. This, that, and the third, he wanna get to know me. Long story short, we hit it off the moment that we hit it off. And we started, like, dating each other. Casually. Not exclusively, but casually. He wanted to change everything about me. It was like something just switched up here. This man would complain about my outfit, my hair, my makeup, my lashes, everything you could think of. All of a sudden, it went from, you look so good, you're so beautiful, blah, blah. Blah to. Why you gotta wear so much makeup everyday? You don't think you can wear smaller lashes? You don't wanna go natural? Why do you need your hair done all the time? You don't wanna just wear your natural hair? Why are you dressing like that? You don't wanna wear this instead? Last time I checked, it was all of this stuff about me that attracted you to me. And now that you got me, you want to change that? It's not gonna happen, y'all. This man literally tried to convince me to wear my natural hair 24 7. No makeup, no lashes anywhere. Skirts that came down to my fucking knees with sneakers and soup socks. It's like they see you and they're like, oh yeah, she bad. I gotta had it. I gotta had it. And then when they get you, it's almost like they're in competition with you. Is like they wanna humble you so bad and I don't know why. Yeah, but long story short, I let that man go cause he was a weird. And I'm still living my best life being as fine as I want.

7371772977093954848.video_description: #stitch with @Freedom Matthews | Author🏹🍂✨ This is my writing story from start to finish.  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #writingstory #writingjourney #storytime
7371772977093954848.voice_to_text: Tell me about your writing journey. I guess I should start from the beginning cause this is actually a shockingly long story. Bear with me. I should preface this by saying that writing runs in my family. My great grandmother so my mum's maternal grandmother she wrote like poetry and stuff I think. And then my mum herself she's a published poet in her own right. She has… how many poetry collections? She's up like six or seven poetry collections out now and also she published a young adult novel called ‘Dart’ which is basically about Dartmoor during the Black Death which is actually really fascinating and not gonna lie. I'm not just saying that. She's my mum. I'm just saying if you see ‘Dart’ by Deborah Harvey you should pick it up. It wasn't necessarily guaranteed that I would turn to writing especially as when you consider what I've just said. You could have said “Oh! That's gonna skip generations maybe the next generations of your family will be writers” but no that's not what happened which is you know interesting. I better start from the beginning of my writing journey then. So my journey starts when I'm 7 I was in year three at primary school and we had been given a creative writing homework. It was essentially just to write a story of a certain I think of a certain word count but I'm not 100% sure on that. The most people told us I'd have a clear beginning, a clear middle, and a clear end. Alright! That works for a 7 year old. I did it. I don't remember too much about what actually happens in the story. In fact I don't remember at all. All I remember is that I'm pretty sure dragon was in it and there was some princesses who weren't like damsels in distress cause clearly I had some feminist energy in me when I was 7. Ha ha! I hand it in. I don't think too much of it until my teacher turned around and said that she'd liked it and she thought I could do this more often. I was like “What” and then I was like “Okay” cause I had enjoyed the process. I had actually enjoyed writing the story even at that age even though it was homework which I didn't like doing too much. So yeah it was really fascinating From there we jump till I was about 11. Now I'm moved on from writing short stories to plays. At this point I was in year six at primary school at this point and we were doing like I think it was towards the end of the year or maybe the middle of the year? I can't remember but we were doing a play and like a big play and there were the play was in segments. So each sort of group of between years three to six had had their own little segment and it would have like a theme and all that stuff. I thought that ours sucked. I'll be honest and that was unusual of me cause I was thought that would sort of just go with it and all the rest of it but I somehow developed the notion of “Oh I should tell my head head teacher this.” So I did and shockingly to me, even to this day, she let me rewrite our entire segment and used it in the play! She let the 11 year old rewrite the play! How weird is that? But yes, we move on from primary school to secondary school and that was a terrible time in my life. Namely because I was bullied for just like everything from the jump and I mean everything. I'm not gonna go into all the details right now but cause that's it that's a story in of itself. So yeah I ended up being very lonely and quite isolated at points and it was a real struggle. I'll be honest. So one of my main comforts was writing. I loved to write little stories but mostly plays and mostly dramas and it was it was a lot of fun for me. To the extent that I didn't wanna do my homework. Sorry Mum. Sorry Dad. Ha ha ha! I then ended up moving on to film scripts when I was about 16/ 17 because I started studying film studies at A-level which I really enjoyed for the most part cause I think film and TV and all the rest… all those mediums can be so transformative when they're good and they can really speak to people. They can change people's lives and I think for the better sometimes. Not always but most of the time it's for the better. I think I then continue… yeah… I continue doing that for quite a long time even when I dropped out of film school at university twice which is so embarrassing. Yeah I dropped out of university twice from university that I don't think even exist anymore. So make a fact what you will and then in my 20s I wrote but not a huge amount purely because I was going through a lot in my early 20s on top of everything I went through like with school and everything else and then I spent a lot of my 20s trying to process that stuff so that I can actually live a productive life and I… so that I could get through without all the trauma being constantly on my brain. Then I got to about 30/31 and I thought to myself: “You know, no one's ever gonna see these films I'm writing and this is just really depressing. What the hell am I going to do?” And then it occurred to me “Wait a minute. What if I turned it into a book? And then maybe people would actually like read it and then maybe someone, if it got really popular somehow, it would turn into a film on its own. Great!” So now we're here. I'm 34 I have one book out there called ‘To Love At Comic Con.’ I am working on the developmental edit for ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’ which I'm hoping will be out towards the end of October and I'm on the first draft of the book after that which has a character in it that I've been trying to develop since I was 15. This has been with me for nearly 20 years! So yeah that's my writing story or more specifically: How did Jenn become a writer? If you enjoyed that then you should stick around. Maybe follow me a little bit because I do enjoy doing these little sort of you know story time videos. They are quite fun.

7370705082771393825.voice_to_text: In a Level 4 prison, I found a dude who made a full pizza oven. I, I let him keep. I get asked about this one of the absolute most fact. Did you actually walk in on someone with a pizza oven and did you really let him keep it? 1. Yes. 2. Yes. Why would I lie? First of all, it's TikTok. Come on. In a prison in Delaware, when I worked as a prison guard. Correctional officer, I did walk in on somebody who was actively using a self made DIY pizza oven. You wanna know how we made it? I'm gonna tell you. No, I am not a mathologist, a scientific boy. But listen up, Mister Pizza. What am I saying? Listen up. Alright, I'm gonna do my best to explain it. Cardboard box inside the inner lining of potato chip bags. At Silver Lining all throughout it. He used what are called stingers, which are two pieces of metal that you put together into the outlet to create the fire. And then the coils kept the fire. And then he would shut it, secure it with a blanket. And then within, like he said, an hour, he had a pizza. And when I found him, I gave him a pizza. In my mind I said, my dude, you have the sauce. But I gotta say, I lost a little bit of crust from that day.

7370438557707603243.voice_to_text: Lieutenant general Donohue just sent out this memo on sleep requirements for staff duty. And, you know, this is a. A great video and some great information from, uh, Viva LA Vargas, uh, with General Donohue when I was at Bragg, uh, well, Fort Liberty. He was, uh, 82nd commander when I was in 18th Airborne Court. Good dude. And it's crazy how long it's taken for a lot of this information to finally make it to a level where someone looks back and says, hey, the way we're operating, it's not smart. Let's do better. You know, when I was stationed up at Fort Drum in 93 94, we were allowed to nap on staff duty. Because many of you don't know, unless you were in back then, how Fort Drum was set up. Well, the economy wasn't that great, so what they did was they took military quarters and they set them out into the rural communities with the hopes of boostering their. Their economy so you could live upwards of almost 30 minutes away from the installation. And, um, a gentleman fell asleep at the wheel on his way home from, uh, CQ and got into a really bad accident. I can't recall if the gentleman died or not, but, um, that spark this whole change of how they were going to operate and conduct, you know, CQ and. And you being on CQ. And there were times, you know, when we would do fuel problems where we would Do continuous up fuel problems. And the maximum amount of sleep we're allowed to get was four hours. And you should do a lot of that stuff. When I was at Bragg, aka Fort Liberty also, so that four hours thing is something that's been around for a long time. When I went to the Scout between leaders course, um, that was another thing we did. They made sure we only got four hours of sleep every night during our. During the time we were out in the field, so on and so forth. So I think it's great that someone is utilizing technology and knowledge that we have nowadays, and they're implementing it to make soldiers lives better. Um, and things like this. Definitely. Definitely a hill worth dying on. I'm not saying. I'm just saying. Great video. Viva! Holler at your boy.
