7364043041281199403.video_description: #stitch with @TYJÚAN a poem breakdown of “The Lovers’ Cry”  #fyp #poetry #love #romance #spirituality #storytime #spokenpoetry #TYJÚAN
7364043041281199403.voice_to_text: so what story was being told let's talk about it so this poem is called The Lovers Cry and this poem is about love and betrayal so in the poem my very first line is I followed the man in the red suit and the man in the red suit is symbolism for my karmic lover  I'm sure we all familiar with what a karmic lover is that is what this poem is about it's about feeling distracted almost so caught up in the lust of it all wanting to be loved that like so bad that you yearn for it and you try so hard to get it and I feel like for me I grew up you know a queer boy in the south you know in a conservative environment I wasn't able to experience love for a big chunk of my life and so the time that I did experience it like love and romance I got caught up in it and I started you know wanting things for the wrong reasons and it all just became this big distraction and what happened was within the story I talked about um being caught up in the charm and the love and the romance but then I'm ravaged by the man in the red suit and what I mean by ravaged is heartbreak and I also mean the death of my ego because I feel like having that heartbreak and going through that heartbreak helped me and initiated my journey to self love and it really changed the trajectory of my life um so I really think that I needed that heartbreak honestly and I'm sure a lot of people out there can relate to that and that's what this poem is about it's about really like learning about what it means to love someone and why you wanna love someone and it taught me that what's meant for me will come to me without me trying to chase it trying to control it trying to force it none of that will be needed you know whatever is meant for me will come to me and so this is just a lesson for anyone out there that's struggling with heartbreak anyone out there that is dealing with not feeling loved I think it's really important to start that journey with yourself and to learn to love yourself unconditionally and to remind yourself of how resilient you resilient you are and how special you are and yeah I feel like knowing who you are from the inside from the within it will attract everything you've ever wanted so I think the goal is to be the best version of yourself first and you won't have to worry about being ravaged um I do personally think that it's something that everyone goes through I think that is a very important part of everyone's journey um this poem has a dark esque to it just because I find it really enjoyable but I also wanted to show the darkness of it of what it could be like to experience love and bliss for the first time but also experiencing heartbreak and sadness for the first time you know and not feeling like you're going to be loved and there is an era of unlearning and there's an era of just sitting in those emotions of feeling insecure feeling very vulnerable feeling betrayed feeling used um you feel all those negative emotions but you remember that those are just what you're feeling right now and it's not forever and you know there is a brighter journey for you ahead and yeah I'm really grateful for this experience and let me know if you enjoyed the poem and if you can relate to the poem as well and yeah thanks for listening

7363970392412753185.voice_to_text: What's a piece of trauma that you have that's funny? It has to actually be funny. I'll go first. My. Thanks so much for asking. I accidentally went on a date with my manager once. Uh, let me tell you what happened. So I used to work on cruise ships, and I was on this thing called portmaning, which is when you're in port and you can't get off the ship, and you work all day, but then you have the evening off, and usually the whole team goes out for dinner afterwards. So my manager's like, do you wanna go out for dinner after work? I was like, yeah, that sounds great. Uh, it was formal night, so finish work, I go back to my cabin, put on a really pretty dress, and go to the restaurant. My manager turns up. He's in a full tuxedo. Tell he's clearly made an effort. I was like, where's the rest of the team? He's like, he didn't ask anyone else. I got tricked. I was on a date with my manager on a floating boat in the middle of the ocean. Nothing I could do. I just had to roll with it. Couldn't say, I've got to get back for the dog. That's not a thing. So, yeah, good times.

7363868917732871466.voice_to_text: what is it you had to be there moment in pop culture that you think about often I'll go first I was wearing my tiara when I dropped my doughnuts it was my Sweet 16 but it was also the worst day of my life not because of an excruciatingly hard ache chemistry class and not because of an extremely rigorous varsity LaCrosse practice but because Zayn the love of my life left one direction that is the beginning of my college common act essay because you just have to be there March 25th, 2015 when Zayn Malik left one direction and for everybody that was around during that day anybody can tell you that it was already a rumor on Twitter we're like oh Zane's gonna leave he left the tour and we're all like no no no no he's just taking a mental health break he's not really gonna pay his way out of one direction why would he do that so that day on my Sweet 16 when I'm at school with my little tiara and I'm carrying my doughnuts I see my friend walking across the parking lot shout out to Tiana one of my besties and she's already crying and I was just like no no I refuse to accept this as reality so I literally collapsed to the ground donuts go flying people on the buses are laughing at me and administrator had to like come and pick me up because I just could not stand them Zayn Malik would leave one direction so not only do I cry through practice I cry over my birthday cake listening to spaces wearing my one direction hoodie I continue to cry for like the next three days with my bestie Tiana and um it was just it was so much you had to be there Zayn Malik I expect some financial compensation for all of that heartbreak it was literal heartbreak on my Sweet 16 I will never forget that

7363848476414840110.voice_to_text: have you heard of the legend of Resurrection Mary? so when I was 15 I created my first feature length film about this ghost named Mary and if you're from the Chicago suburbs you've probably heard of this legend so I didn't get permission to film at this resurrection cemetery where the story takes place but I went there to get b roll to make it look like I shot at that cemetery. So, I was at the gates where this ghost infamously runs through these gates and disappears and I decided I was gonna do an EVP. I was a ghost hunter at the time when I was 15 I would you know go to cemeteries and do Evps and I decided to do one at Resurrection Cemetery. So, I start the voice memo and I respectfully asked a bunch of questions related to Mary. I wanted to contact Resurrection Mary that was the plan and start asking a bunch of questions you know what is your name how did you pass away do you need help questions like that I don't see anything I don't hear anything but I get this deep intuition that something just isn't right… and I ran to the car and my dad said did you catch anything and I said no I was a little bummed out but he's like play back the recording so we do and after the question what is your name it says don't ask. In this deep angry demonic voice it was horrifying I didn't sleep after that and it was the end of my ghost hunting career. it will forever haunt me hopefully actually not haunt me but it freaked me out and there is a lot of stories that I have about my ghost hunting experiences but this one will forever stick with me I'd love to hear your ghost stories in the comments below and have a great day but remember to always say goodbye

In support of setting standards for your kids, why don't we get ready together? Well, I talk about our strict rules. Number one, my kids need to read at least 30 minutes a day, even on the weekends. We have seen that kids simply cannot read. Seventh graders are reading at a third grade level, and high schoolers are reading at a sixth grade level every single day. That is a must. Number two is no phones allowed in your bedroom. This only really applies to my oldest, but if you need to make a phone call, you can do that downstairs in another room. I do not want your phone in your room. So we do no screen time Monday through Thursday. So no phone unless you need to call a friend. And no TV. Kids are so busy with homework, after school activities, dinner anyway, that there's really no time. Obviously in the summer that changes. And when they do get screen time, we do set limits on that as well. Hour on the phone maximum. Of course, TV is a little over two hours if they're watching a movie. Do not allow our kids to use their phones or ipads at restaurants at all. This was a really hard one to let go of when we did Allow our kids to bring devices into restaurants. They displayed zombie like behaviours. Screen time free for over two years. And it has made such a big difference. And actually have conversations. We can laugh, we can talk. And I wanna make it very clear that this doesn't apply for every kid, but this is what worked for us. And the last strict rule for us. While it might be controversial, you are absolutely hundred percent expected to do well in school. And if they are struggling, we will absolutely help them with what they need to succeed. Of course, every kid is different, and I'm sure there are challenges along the way. But we know that our kids are very capable of doing well in school. And this is what works for us. 7371849483396681002.voice_to_text: The world's first head transplant machine has been unveiled. Brainbridge created a concept using AI and robotics to transplant a human head. It could offer New Hope to those suffering from untreatable conditions such as terminal cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. Modern medicine has been unable to properly reconnect the nerves and spinal cord. Until a way is found, any head transplants would result in paralysis. However, some scientists believe they found a chemical capable of the near impossible task, polyethylene glycol. But can it be done?

My mom had me when she was 32. So, you know, she could have had another baby before my sister, who's 11 years older than me. It would have worked out just fine. You know, my brother's just four years older than me. So I'm like, who is she? Where is she? Like, what happened to her? And my mom told me and my brother that. So here I am, maybe four years old, my brother is, like, 8 years old, and we think that our older sister died, blew herself up on the toilet because she was smoking a Marlboro 100 menthol and just happened to fart and just blow herself up and blow up the side of the bathroom. In the same house that we were living in, for years we thought this was true. For years we told people about this. For years, I felt sorry for her. 7371587535270595883.voice_to_text: Who said I love you first? great question so we met in March of 2015 uh we both knew each other were the one right away but we did not say I love you as fast as you planned this like huge trip to Paris at the end of the summer to celebrate his internship being over so I'm a big romantic and so I wanted the moment when I told her I love you for the first time to be really special we then went to Paris for our first big international trip together keep in mind like people were asking me if we were gonna get engaged in Paris and I was like he literally hasn't even said I love you like all my friends said that too. we’re definitely not getting engaged basically all our friends and family thought we were gonna get engaged in Paris I’m like, not gonna happen selling roses I buy a rose we're walking down the river Seine it's nighttime we walk out onto a bridge because we want a really good view of the Eiffel Tower we didn't know this would happen but right as we get to the center of the bridge right as I'm about to tell her the Eiffel Tower lights up as it always does at night on the hour and so in that perfect moment exactly as the Eiffel Tower lit up I told Campbell I love you for the first time and we both burst into tears and it was just the most magical moment to this day that trip to Paris is one of our greatest trips ever if not the very best I just love the Eiffel Tower so much as cliche as that is I don't care it's so beautiful and like seeing it light up for the first time it's just the most magical thing and then you saying I love you at the same time I thought he had planned it but I guess he really didn't well I planned it to be on the bridge looking out at the Eiffel Tower but I didn't realize It was gonna light up at that exact hotel and we're holding hands and we're madly in love and the Campbell does what she often does and says I have to pee little known fact Campbell has to pee like every five seconds I have to pee a 7370773201707715886.voice_to_text: When did you first realize what it means to be black in America? I was hanging out with someone the other day, and they asked me a really interesting question. They asked me when I first realized that I was black. Also, I got straight out of bed and came to work out, so don't mind my crusty parents right now. Um, anyway, they asked me when I first realized I was black. And it's a whole story for me, as I'm sure it is for a lot of people, but I realized my first day of kindergarten, like, day one, that I was black and that that meant something. Actually, don't even remember this. My mom had to tell me about it. Not because I was too young, but it's because I was living in Ohio at the time. And I have blocked out large portions of those years, mostly because of the racial bullying I experienced during that time and how traumatic it was for me. And there was also, like, family illnesses and other things. But. Anyway, I got in the car after my first day of kindergarten, and I instantly asked my mom, like, are white people smarter than black people? And she was like, why would you ask that? And I was basically like, well, the teacher treats me like I'm less intelligent than the other students. So I assume she thinks I don't have the right answers or something, because she never calls on Me? That sounds super worthy. But that's how I talked as a kid. So the point is, it only took me one day in a certain type of white environment to notice that blackness was a thing, and then to internalize some of the negative things that come with that. So I guess my question for other black people is.

7370743810139131179.voice_to_text: So I've had a lot of conversations with people about that speech that the kickball player did like a week or so ago, and the responses I've gotten from Catholic people and religious people in general have all been the same response. And I have some questions, and I would love it if y'all would put your thinking caps on to try to help me get an answer to these questions, because I have yet to have anybody answer it. So when I have said that the speech he gave was misogynistic and horrible, the Catholics tend to respond to me saying that he was simply stating the truth of the Catholic faith. And the Catholic faith has very defined gender roles. And it is only natural for women to be happier at home as homemakers and mothers, and it's only natural for men to be happier as leaders of their households, which is convenient. Um, but here's my question then. If these are natural roles that are agreed upon by everyone in your faith, and not only that, they are deeply rooted in your faith, why do you have to keep reminding the women of that? You know, I'm just curious. Because you'd think if it was natural and this wasn't agreed upon thing, you probably wouldn't have to, like, keep reminding them of the place that you have predefined for them. I don't know. Especially when you are giving a commencement speech at a graduation and you are Addressing women who have made their choice, and that choice was to pursue an education and a career and a passion that is. That doesn't mean it's purely exclusive from motherhood. You can, in fact, have both. But you'd go to assume that if they spent four ish years and tens of thousands of dollars obtaining a degree, they probably plan on using it, you know, and there's nothing wrong with being a homemaker. Let me just say that. The point is choice. You should choose to be a homemaker and a mother. That should be something that you want to do, not that you feel pressured or shamed into doing. You know, and especially when in the first minute and 50 seconds of your graduation commencement speech, you decide to talk about women's access to healthcare and whether or not they should be able to choose if they stay pregnant or not. When that's in the first minute and 50 seconds of your commencement speech, it's almost like choice is what you have a problem with. You know, you're like, hmm, I really wish I wasn't addressing these women right now. I should really just remind them that they should be barefoot and pregnant at home. That's what it sounds like. 7370327400825015594.voice_to_text: No, this. This right here is my fundamental problem. You are saying that every single adult attending a party shouldn't drink because there's kids there. No. If you are choosing to bring your kid, you shouldn't be drinking, because you, the parent, are the ones watching them, and you, the parents, are the one responsible for them. That has nothing to do with everybody else who's choosing to attend that event. They're allowed to have a drink or two because they're not responsible for that unattended child. You, on the other hand, you are responsible for that child, because not only are you that child's parent, you're the one who chose to bring them to that environment, knowing it would be full of adults who are drinking and dancing and partying. It's like taking your child to a bar and then being like, oh, my gosh, can you not play music with, like, bad words in it? Or telling other patrons that they need to watch their language because their children present, that's not their problem. It is an environment that is pretty much not meant for kids, that you choose to bring kids into, and that is on you to watch and supervise your child. It is not communal babysitting

7370105749541981486.video_description: A lonely tortoise turned to online dating to find a girlfriend after previously attempting to start a relationship with a rock. 🪨 Thanks to tortoise tinder, he met Estrella, and the couple moved in together after carrying on a long-distance relationship via video calls first. 🐢  Hugo and Estrella live at the Australian Reptile Park and they post regular updates about their animals! ❤️  See more from the couple: @AustReptilePark  📸 Australian Reptile Park  #tortoise #galapagostortoise #relationshipgoals #animalcouple #relationships #couplethings #wildlife #reptiles
7370105749541981486.voice_to_text: A lonely tortoise who previously had a rock for a girlfriend finally turned to online dating and started a long distance relationship with an actual tortoise. Now that they're together in person, their relationship has been thriving. Hugo, the Galapagos tortoise, spent seven decades without ever having a girlfriend. He's lived at the Australian Reptile Park since 1963 when he was brought there as an ambassador for his endangered species, and while he's very well cared for, over the years he started showing more signs of being lonely, including trying to start a relationship with a goose named Lenny and then trying to start one with a shell shaped rock in his habitat, neither of which worked out. But finding him a girlfriend wasn't an easy task. These species is protected and there are more restrictions than there were in the 60s, so it's not exactly easy to just acquire a Galapagos tortoise anymore. The reptile park created a tinder profile for him and ran a paid post on social media showcasing his profile to see if any other sanctuaries might have a lonely female tortoise of their own. They were in luck because a zoo in Germany came forward with a potential match, a 21 year old Galapagos tortoise named Estrella. Hugo swiped right on Estrella because she needed to be quarantined before she could move to Australia to be with him. They started a long distance relationship with regular video call dates while they waited. And when they Finally met in person. The spark was there. 7368994788391292206.voice_to_text: I think it is you, the women, who have had the most diabolical lies told to you. How many of you are sitting here now, about to cross this stage and are thinking about all the promotions and titles you are going to get in your career? Some of you may go on to lead successful careers in the world, but I would venture to guess that the majority of you are most excited about your marriage and the children you will bring into this world. I can tell you that my beautiful wife, Isabel, would be the first to say that her life truly started when she began living her vocation as a wife and as a mother. By making it to this moment through all the adversity thrown your way from COVID, I hope you learn the important lessons that suffering in this life is only temporary. As a group, you witnessed firsthand how bad leaders who don't stay in their lane can have a negative impact on society. While COVID might have played a large role throughout your formative years, it is not unique. Bad policies and poor leadership have negatively impacted major life issues. Things like abortion, IVF, surrogacy, euthanasia, as well as a growing support for degenerate cultural values in media, all stem from the pervasiveness of this order. Our own nation is LED by a man who publicly and proudly proclaims his Catholic faith, but at the same time is delusional enough to make The sign of the cross during a pro abortion rally. He has been so vocal in his support for the murder of innocent babies that I'm sure to many people, it appears that you can be both Catholic and pro choice. The world around us says that we should keep our beliefs to ourselves. Whenever they go against the tyranny of diversity, equity and inclusion, we fear speaking truth. Because now, unfortunately, truth is in the minority. Congress just passed a Bill we're stating. Something as basic as the biblical teaching of who killed Jesus? Could land you in jail. I'm certain the reporters at the AP did not have imagined that their attempt to rebuke and embarrass places and people like those here have been addicting. Wouldn't be met with anger, but instead met with excitement and pride. Not the deadly sins sort of pride that has an entire month dedicated to it, but the true god centered pride that is cooperating with the Holy Ghost to glorify him.

the video I talked about when I worked for Louis Vuitton back in college and there were generally two main discounts we got 70% off of RTV which is return to vendor these are bags that were like slightly damaged or imperfect and it was sold to employees kind of at a lotto system depending on the availability and then the other main discount was 30% off of straight up full price merchandise in store The boyfriend of one of my college like acquaintance friends at the time asked me if he could use my employee discount and buy a Louis Vuitton bag for his girlfriend for her birthday and the official rule is that the 70% off the higher percentage discount employees could not use that discount to buy things as gifts for family and friends it was only stuff that you bought for yourself and then for the 30% off you could use that to purchase gifts for family and friends but in either case you weren't allowed to lend your discount to other people it was only for gifts at 30 off or stuff for yourself at the 70 off I am a girl's girl and times are tough so I was you know feeling generous and I was like you know why not I'm not using it I really only use the 70% off and then once I was maxed out then I didn't really buy anything for the 30 off because it was still very expensive so I was like sure you can use my discount I calculated the exact like to the penny what he would owe with the discount and with tax you know I wasn't trying to like make money off of him I wasn't charging him a fee to use my discount I just was being generous I thought I bought the bag with my discount had it nicely gift wrapped and gave it to him and he gave me the cash for it should have preface this but in either case whether it's 70 or 30 off you could not return anything like these sales were final final sales non returnable and I told this to the guy also and I said okay are you sure this is the bag she wants it was a speedy 30 monogram like are you sure because most girls at our age wanted a speedy 25 which is the smallest of the speedy sizes and he was like no she wanted the 30 you know he was like adamant I was like okay you know for sure like she tried it on she wants this monogram she doesn't want damier a whatever and he was like no this is what she wants and I was like okay and I told him like this is not returnable this is final sale got him the bag and he gave it to his girlfriend whenever her birthday was the following like that weekend or whatever and then I don't hear anything he told me thank you when I gave it to him and then I get a call or a text I don't remember if I got a text but I vividly remember the phone call because it started off with the girl saying hey Cindy unfortunately the bag isn't gonna work out haha I was like what okay like uh that's not my problem you're gonna have to make it work or do something with it because this like I'm not Walmart I'm not returning a bag for you I like let you use the discount but that's it you cannot return this I think yeah I'm pretty sure I didn't give him the receipt because you know it's final sale and I have to hold on to those cause it has my name attached to it and whatever so I don't know what she ended up doing with it but no thank you or anything from her just that oh it's not gonna work out and I was like oh my god and I remember being scared that they were going to like try to bring it back to the store but like at that point I was like you do not bring this back to the store and return it or try to exchange it because like I will get in trouble so I got really like I got really annoyed I don't know I got really annoyed by that I actually don't know what ended up happening I don't know if she kept it if she regifted it to someone if she sold it or maybe tried to exchange it without the receipt but I didn't get in trouble thank god because I would have been very upset because I was working at LV at that point I was working full time and still going to college full time so um anyway so that's why I don't share my discount with anyone

said I was street smart and back then my anxiety was more the like I think I have rabies for no discernible reason kind of anxiety rather than that everyone's a threat anxiety that I've since added into the mix so invite her in and she sits at my dining room table and I bring her a glass of water which she promptly chugs and I go on the kitchen to refill her glass of water and suddenly she's right behind me so she starts opening my cabinets and she's looking all around my kitchen and I'm so stunned I'm just standing there doing absolutely nothing so this apartment was pretty big it was a three bedroom two bathroom apartment that I only paid $570 a month for and off the kitchen there was a really long hallway that LED to the the bedrooms so she starts going down the hallway and she opens the first bedroom door which had nothing in it because I did a cheap apartment but I didn't actually have any stuff to put it inside no money so she's like why don't you have any stuff in here and I'm like I just don't have any stuff so she keeps going and she opens the next door which is a bathroom the next door which is a closet and she starts to open the second bedroom door but luckily I of corral her back to the dining room she sits down and I give her the new glass of water and the living room the dining room are like an L shaped configuration so she kind of turns in her seat and 7367119510354038059.voice_to_text: we need to start preparing young women for the workplace drama that involves just a random old lady having one sided beef with random old white women in corporate America being like the biggest bullies you've ever encountered like so rude for no reason it's something that nobody on this planet prepared me for and we need to talk about it cause like why for what why is a random 45 year old woman named Linda beefing with me for no reason at all let me be clear when I start a new job I am a people pleaser like I am overly nice I want everyone to get along because I don't wanna keep going through the whole repeated pattern of like oh we're like a big family like toxic corporate work culture thing that keeps happening and it's literally the reason like I do freelance work now I don't wanna deal with these weird dynamics in workplaces cause recently I went down a side of TikTok where it was like women of colour coming forward and sharing that white women in corporate America were some of the worst people they have to deal with and I fully support them because they truly are their reasons for feeling that way are probably a lot different than mine but they really are and I genuinely don't know why because like is it good old fashioned misogyny they still genuinely like believe there isn't enough space in the corporate world for all women so they have to turn it into like a weird competition constantly I've worked in a number of them now and there's always at least one woman in there somewhere that is just determined to make your life miserable one job I had my boss was a woman and I noticed that everyone they hired for our department they purposely hired both women and women who were like super super young and I mean like they were either still in college or they had just graduated like that year they had to be 21 because she had a tendency to really infantilise all the people who reported to her and like wanted to be like a mentor that people looked up to but kinda like we're never on her level and I remember one day it's uh left out somehow that I was actually 24 and she thought the whole time I was like 20 or 21 and it was just a little bit awkward that was only where the problems began to start though because then one day when she was out of the office and like her boss though was in um he walked in on me doing some random work cause I got bored I finished all my work so I logged into the back end of the website we worked in marketing right but I have a degree in like uxy and all that other stuff and since I was bored I was fixing the coding and whatnot on the back end of the website asked my boss if I could do it she was like sure you got time cause the website was really messed up and he walked in you know we were chit chatting we were having a good time he saw that I was doing this and asked me about it and he was like really impressed he didn't know that I could do this and I was like yeah I mean no one's ever really asked me what my background is here at the company and literally like a few minutes later after he leaves I get an email cced with like my boss and other people that I've been promoted essentially aka they're just gonna pay me more but essentially the message of the email was like oh we see that you have a lot of value that you're important to the company and we like wanna make sure that you stay here and that's when the problems with my boss who sat above me really started I don't know exactly why but she started making my day to day life very difficult with like menial things for no reason like she would write up all the random mistakes that happened in the office not always mine not usually mine some of them were hers too and she would report me to HR so I'd have to go to HR and I don't know how to argue that like my boss is saying I did this ironically after that I then got written up and sent to HR for asking too many clarifying questions about stuff that I should know however I was just trying to make sure we didn't have any more mistakes at the company like it started to be a running joke in our department cause I was chill with everyone else in the department that like at any random given moment I could be just sent to HR to be lectured and yelled at or things that really just didn't make any sense it was like a funny running joke in the office because like everyone else was also starting to have problems with her so I felt pretty comforted in that fact but even back to the point where I was like crying in the bathroom at work most days and she still yelled at me for doing that because it was unprofessional but I specifically remember one day our big boss came back from a lunch with one of our co workers and so he was hanging out in like our office cause literally like six of us shared an office it was a really weird setup but we were all hanging out having fun we were joking we were laughing he and I were like shooting jokes back and forth and we were laughing our butts off I thought it was like a really good day and then I look over at her in the corner and she's giving me like the evilest look I've ever seen in my life and I don't know why I can't figure out why but I know that I'm about to be off once he leaves the room but after he leaves she literally just like packs up and leaves for the day and then the next day I come into the office and of course I get called into HR and she has told HR that everyone in our department all like seven or eight of us apparently have written up that they're uncomfortable with my behaviour at work and I'm sitting here bawling in HR cause I have no idea I everyone hates me essentially is what she's saying like no one wants me there like and I don't know what to say to that and I'm like could you give me some examples like I I don't wanna make everyone uncomfortable like could you tell me what I could do to change they can't give me a single example because there are none I remember I'm bawling she says go take a walk before you go back to the office because like I don't want people seeing this and I was just like no I went straight back to the office where all our co workers were bawling they're like what happened like what did you get written up for this time there's like apparently every single one of you filed a report about me and everyone's looking at each other going literally no one in here has ever complained about you once and they were all so sweet and understanding and comforting to me in that moment like I knew they were telling the truth but I did not wanna continue to fight this grown lady and our HR over this so I just wrote like my 2 weeks notice and I turned it in the next day and left the company and I won't lie slowly but surely pretty much everyone left after me because they also had these problems but I've definitely experienced like stuff like this in other companies too and I just don't understand like do they just not think we can all coexist is it because it's like marketing and like marketing is considered a young person's game so they feel threatened like I don't know but it's wild and no one tells you that this is going to be another thing you get to deal with later in life

7366082734806060334.voice_to_text: this is one of the most painful conditions any person can have it is called a polynatyl abscess and it is formed because of an infection in these polynatyl sinuses which is a passageway between the coxas or the tail bone in your skin and what happens is that often we see this in individuals who are overweight males those who are sitting for a period long periods of time but we could also see it in women and what happens is you have an ingrown hair that gets stuck in these sinuses and eventually over time become infected causing fluid to accumulated causing an infection called an abscess in the way that we manage this is by surgery so often times we perform surgery to get rid of these infection they are seeing how they perform the surgery so the way they do it is they essentially form an incision on that passageway and surgeons are able to get rid of these ingrown hair because the key is to remove the ingrown hair so that doesn't accumulate and cause infection and then they also laser this passageway to form scar tissue so the sinuses are closed so that this infection doesn't reoccur again so what's important here is that if you fit that demographic of a male overweight who sits for prolonged periods of time and you're having tailbone pain make sure you talk to a primary care provider to make sure you don't have a pile of metal abscess because those could be life threatening

7365910544160771359.video_description: Help me get this video out there! #letsgo @Erin Hattamer
7365910544160771359.voice_to_text: Hi. I'm not sure how many of you are aware that content creator Aaron Hadtimer has started an initiative where she is partnering up other creators and influencers with families in Gaza who have Gofundme's in order to help raise money and evacuate as many people as possible. We all know that no one person can do it all, so she is assigning some of us volunteers, our adopted families, to maximize reach and help raise as many funds as possible. When I Learned about this, I knew I wanted to participate, but the algorithm doesn't always favor me, so I'm gonna need a lot of your help in the upcoming weeks to try to reach my adopted family school. This is the Shaheen family. A father, a mother, two sons, and their respective families, including two very, very young children. Their daughter, Amani, was lucky enough to leave Gaza, and she is organizing this gofundme on their behalf. Family is currently in the south of Gaza in a building that's housing over 80 other displaced people. There is not enough food or water, and they all take turns sleeping because there is also not enough mattresses or blankets. This includes the babies, Yusuf, who's only three and a half years old, and baby Ahmed, who is just a year old. Ahmed has osteomalycia, which obviously can't be properly treated where they are. I will be posting about the Shaheen family until their goal of £60,000 is raised. I am Begging you all to give what you can, even if all you can is $5. There are enough of us on this platform to truly make a difference. Even if we all pull together, we can get this family out of Gaza through the Egyptian border, which is a money's ultimate goal. Please help by liking, commenting, sharing, reposting, and go to the link in my bio to find their gofundme. I know that we can't help everyone everywhere, as much as we may like to, but we can help here. Let's help this family, please.

7365887640555523360.video_description: this is from the perspective of an independent unsigned solo artist who would need to hire session musicians to form a band. the winner doesn't only have to pay for travel and accommodation for themselves and their band, but they would also need to pay the musicians they hire - unless they're lucky enough to not have to pay them as sometimes musicians will agree to do these things for free, for example if they're your friend. all of these plus various unexpected costs that pop up. this whole 'play for exposure and do it for free' really contributes to the exploitation of artists - it's not fair, we need to start getting paid for our time and efforts, and stop going to these awful promoters for gigs and opportunities. sure I love what I do I love singing on stage and writing songs etc but I'm reaching a point where I understand what I'm worth and I'm less willing to entertain things like this. and lots of other artists are as well and I'm here for it. dont get me wrong there are some instances where I would gig for free but in those instances I would get compensation/value from something else, whether that's free food and drink or the opportunity to work with some really influential people. #livemusic #promoters #newmusic #singing #independentartist
7365887640555523360.voice_to_text: isle of white competition update basically I didn't win and that's fine I wasn't expecting to win but I'm actually kind of glad that I didn't win because I ended up connecting with one of the winners from previous years and they essentially said that it's completely unpaid and not only that you're expected to cover the travel costs and accommodation costs of not just for yourself but also for your band members easily at least a couple of thousand and I'm like okay thank God I didn't win it because I just can't afford that right now because I quit my job and I'm currently back home in Greece figuring things out but yeah just got me thinking that it's so bad that they don't offer any financial assistance or they don't even pay you for coming out and performing at the Isle of Wight which is a big festival over the last few weeks there's been a lot of conversation on TikTok about  London based promoters and about how a lot of them clearly don't care about artists and a lot of them are downright scammers as well like there's a lot of pay to play out there competition was through hot vox and hot vox is not the worst promoter out there but it's just quite sad how both hot vox and the organisers for the Isle of Wight Festival  aren't willing to at least somehow help out the person who wins this competition because expecting an artist to just fork out thousands and thousands of pounds to come and play at Isle of Wight it's just quite I don't know it just doesn't sit right with me the fact this is completely unpaid is absolutely appalling of course you need to pay the artist who's performing especially at this big festival here's an update on the competition and I am glad that I didn't win I know that I will eventually get to Isle of Wight Festival but probably not through this competition  there's definitely other ways to get there

Then, after you watch the video, blow up these buttons over here.  like comment  please keep the comments relevant to this video it's really important that we talk about Gaza we talk about Reemy and her family and then save it and repost it you repost by hitting the share button and then it's the first button I think it's yellow.  If every single one of my followers donated $1 their goal would be met end of story. I know we can do this and I feel so grateful that the Creator Fund has given me the financial ability to give a 500 Euro* donation to this family thank you so much for watching the entire video!  have a great rest of your day!

7365877470391815467.voice_to_text: If you are a black person and you have all white friends, or you're surrounded by white people 24 7, as a fellow black person, yes, I look at you funny. And stories like this are the exact reason why I look at you funny. Man makes miracle recovery after allegedly being pushed into a lake by his friends and he was left underwater. After being hospitalized for more than two weeks, a 26 year old man from Louisiana is officially off life support. Doctors described Christopher Gilbert's survival as a miracle after allegedly being pushed into a lake by his friends and left underwater for nearly ten minutes. Gilbert and a group of his friends were at a lakefront restaurant when he ended up in the water, leaving him with significant rain damage and on life support. His friends, right? Family attorney Claudia Payne said Gilbert's friend group initially reported to police that he had fallen into the lake. However, after an investigation was conducted, it was said that he was allegedly pushed into the water by a girl in the friend group. Gilbert's legal team is demanding and arrest be made. They also want the restaurant owners to be held accountable for not keeping him safe. So far, no arrests have been made and activists are demanding justice and answers. I'm not even an activist and I need answers. I want answers like now. But let's get into the real story, you feel me? A white woman pushed An aspiring black doctor into a lake knowing he couldn't swim. The woman also lied to his parents and the police saying he fell into the lake. They also watched him for 10 minutes struggling before bystanders who did not know him intervened. Uh huh. And I know when said friends concocted this little plan, cause this was definitely premeditated. I'm not hearing it was premeditated. When they sat there, got together, and made up this little plan of what they was gonna do, they did not think of the possibility of him surviving it. They thought he was going to drown that way. They already had the story that they wanted to tell. It was already set in stone. This man was on his way to be a doctor. He was on his way to make a change in this world. A black man on his way to greatness. And they tried to stop him from that. You would like to donate to Chris's cause? I've already donated. The link to his gofundme is under this thread on Twitter is still up, so just type in that name and you'll be able to find it. Mr. Chris, we see what's going on. We know what's going on, just like you know what's going on. And we are behind you. We as in black people. We are behind you. I promise you.

7365596664499064110.voice_to_text: Gen Xers and also Europeans, was it normal for your parents to leave you alone at night and go out on a date after you were in bed? No babysitters. So my husband and I were talking about the comments on this video where this comment was left, and, like, he was a latchkey kid and was left alone starting at age 5 during the day. And I was sharing a different situation in which we were left alone as very, very young children. And maybe it's because we lived in Germany. And that's why I was saying, like, hey, Europeans, what. What is your experience? Because I think it was much more common in Germany in the early eighties that when you put your kid in the crib at night, like, they're expected to be in bed. They're safe. They're in a crib. Nothing bad is gonna happen to them. So you can go out on a date. You don't need. You don't need childcare. You don't need a sitter. They're in bed. What's gonna happen to them? They're definitely not gonna have issues in the middle of the night. They're definitely not gonna get out of bed and need a parent. They're in bed. We told them to stay in bed. Why not have a date? And you definitely don't need a babysitter. Why would you pay someone to be supervising your kid who is just sleeping in bed? And my husband, the lash key kid, thought that Was wild. So, Americans, was that something that happened to you, or was that kind of a European experience? And Europeans, is that something that y'all still do today? Because I know here in America, we would never consider, like, once our kids are tucked in for the night, that we can just go out and do whatever. And there doesn't need to be a responsible caregiver in the house. I certainly could never imagine having left my infant at home while I went out on a date, like Home Alone. Thinking about how parents justified that as good parenting is. Yeah.

7365525091980954923.video_description: plz take care of ya cat bites, the more you know #takecareofyou #catbite #catsoftiktok
7365525091980954923.voice_to_text: fun fact of the day if you get bit by your cat and it draws blood you should go to urgent care yesterday my cat bit me and it was completely my fault she was trying to bite the corner of my Kindle and I thought it would be a smart idea to put my finger where she was biting and of course she bit my finger and I've been scratched before and I've been bit before so like I didn't think anything of it I just went about my day but started noticing that my finger was getting a little bit more swollen and red and it like was hard to bend so I read online if it's red and swollen painful you should probably go see a doctor so I went to urgent care first thing this morning and they prescribed me with an antibiotic they had to report it to animal control which really stressed me out but it was a super quick conversation with animal control they just asked me if my cat was up to date on its vaccines and whether it was indoor and outdoor and that was it and I'm very much of the mindset that it's like oh like it's no big deal like I'll tough it out but good thing I didn't cause it can actually lead to some pretty intense infections if not treated with antibiotics yeah I didn't know that

7365503111747816750.voice_to_text: So in lieu of recent videos that I have done, I have a couple stories for people now. I advocate for the clients. I think it's important for clients to be educated, but I will also stand up for artists, because education and the truth are invaluable. So I got a couple stories. About 10 years ago, I tattooed in Florida. And in Florida, you can tattoo minors as low as the age of 16, as long as you have parental consent. High school kid comes in, big Samoan. He wants some Samoan tribal. I do my best. He's happy, she's happy. All is good. I go over strict aftercare with every client I tattoo, especially in the last 10 to 15 years, because I noticed a trend. Wash the tattoo three to five times a day with gold dial antibacterial soap. Uh, let it air dry for about 15 minutes. Then use a regular amount of white unscented lotion. It's not a cupcake. You do not need to ice it. Anyway, this kid gets his tattoo. So two to three weeks later, him and the mom come back in, and she is very upset. She is demanding that we pay for doctor visits, medicine, and she wants her money back for the tattoo. The kid lifts his sleeve up, he's keloided. Uh, there's a clear infection. And the shop that I work at, we took health standards pretty serious. So I start asking questions. Well, come to find out, This kid wasn't taking care of his tattoo the way I told him. He was also picking the scabs causing the keloid. And after further conversation, unbeknownst to the mother, he'd went to football practice, put on dirty shoulder pads with a sleeveless shirt on. And they wondered where he got the staff infection from. Second story. I did a tattoo on a young lady's foot. Part of my aftercare is do not submerge your tattoo for 10 to 14 days. And when I say submerge, I tell them I mean a pond, a river, a swimming pool, a hot tub, a bathtub. She comes back in a week later, her tattoo looks terrible. Come to find out through conversation, she went to the beach the next day. She thought it was okay because when I said, don't submerge it in a body of water, I didn't list off the beach. So don't be so quick to blame the tattoo artist all the time. Because some of you don't know how to follow fucking directions. Have the day you deserve.

7365308271420345642.voice_to_text: Tell me a ghost story that sounds completely unbelievable but is entirely true. When I tell this story to this day, people do not believe me. When I was a freshman in college, I was going to a private school in Pittsburgh. I was leaving the next year. I was going to a different school. So my friends and I, some of us were leaving, some of us were moving, whatever. We decided we wanted to kind of hit all the different spots in Pittsburgh that we really like. So we went to, like, Mount Washington, for those of you don't know, it's like a really nice lookout over Pittsburgh. And there was a place near our school, and it was called the fountain of youth. It was essentially just like a well that people in the town used to go to when it was in use. So we went there. It was night time. It wasn't like midnight. It was like nine or so. It wasn't super late. Um, we went there, and the way that this well was set up, it was, like, carved. There was a piece carved out of a rock formation, and then you'd walk in and then get water out of the well inside of it. So the. The people who are, like, shorter or smaller, they went inside and, like, I'm tall, so I wasn't gonna, like, go in there, but other girls were going inside and just, like, checking it out and seeing What it looked like. And the rest of us were standing outside taking pictures, just like, messing around, waiting, hanging out, you know, talking. The girls inside, one of them said, hey, I can kind of hear, like, rocks moving around in here. It sounds like there's something else in here. And we were all like, okay, well, that's probably an animal. So just like, come out. So as she's like, leaving and coming out and saying, like, I can hear something in here, the girls who are outside, my. Me specifically, my phone died. Turned off completely. It was at 70, 80%. It was not anywhere close to dying. Turned off, died. Other girls phone started dying. Then we heard a growl. And it did not sound like a animal. It sounded more like a human being. Trying to mimic what an animal sounds like when they growl. And we found this out later. That the girls inside the cave heard the same exact thing. Coming from inside the cave. We heard it outside in the woods. We all run and book it to the car. We get back, we're all like, we're done. That's it. Whatever. I'm going to take a shower. I'm changing. And I see in the mirror, handprints on my shoulder. Like someone just grabbed it like that and left those prints. I tell everybody, check yourselves, because I just found this on myself. The one girl who was in the well lifts up her Shirt, I look, she has three scratch marks down her back. I was like, nope, we're done. I started praying. I said, if there's something attached to us, get it away from us. I want no part of that. And that was it.

7364092507170295086.video_description: Did your job teach you something surprising? Share your story & inspire others! CC: @morganwithpolish #CareerDevelopment #RealTalk #jobtips #jobsearch #corporate #9to5 #learnontiktok #hr #workplace #fyp #fypシ #viral #workplacetiktok #corporatetiktok #ourcareerlounge
7364092507170295086.voice_to_text: Me. Something a job has taught you that you will never, ever forget, no matter what. That they don't care. They don't care that you got in a wreck on the way to work. They don't care that your babysitter didn't show up. They don't care that you just bought a house. This is coming from someone who sat on the executive board, with the CEO, with the C O O, with all of the higher UPS. They don't care. They don't care what you have going outside of work. It is about the result. It is about the deliverable. And the sooner you remove the emotion out of the work that you do, the further that you can go. Because when you start to think that they care if you had a bad day, then you give yourself an excuse to have a bad day. When you think that they hear that you're doing really well in your personal life, you give yourself an excuse. When you remove the emotion, you will go further. Show up, be passionate about the work that you were doing. If you are. If you don't care about the work you're doing, do the bare minimum, but take the emotion out of it. And stop people thinking that people care. It wasn't until I understood this that I doubled my salary and was able to get promoted. It sounds cold, but it's true.

7363027936246582570.voice_to_text: I asked annexers if you left at 18 or were kicked out, and that comment thread and the subsequent follow up video to that have almost 35 comments of Gen Xers and elder millennials talking about their experience of being booted out or leaving right after they graduated from high school because of the way they had a toxic relationship with their parents. And this was a really common sentiment in those comments. So if you were a Gen X or an elder millennial, I'd love to know did you feel that you were wanted by your parents, or did you feel that they treated you as nothing more than a societal obligation and a tax break? And if it's the latter, how did that shape you? How did that change your life, and how did that shape the way you relate to children and families? Because I've seen a number of folks commenting that they chose not to have kids specifically because of how they were treated as children, and that the coldness and lack of affection from their parents really made it difficult to have relationships with other adults as well. So did you feel that you were wanted by your parents, or did you feel like you were just an obligation?

7362971098423545121.video_description: This sad proposal story *will* make you cry & gets a ‘BIG THUMBS UP’ from us 👍🏼😭 OUT TOMORROW! 🥺 #newlywedspodcast #jamieandsophie
7362971098423545121.voice_to_text: I've been with my boyfriend for nearly six years now, but we had previously met when we were 11. Many years ago, a year into our relationship, lockdown hit and we were forced with the decision to lock down together or not. It was also during this time that my amazingly brave dad got diagnosed with Parkinson's disease and the years that followed turned out to be the hardest years of my life, juggling work and being a carer full time. I've been teasing my boyfriend about getting married, but I just knew it wasn't the right time as my focus was making my dad feel comfy and safe in the last year of his life. I knew dad loved my boyfriend as his only communication with us at the end was a thumbs up and he would always do that to my boyfriend when he came to see him. Very sadly, but extremely peacefully, my dad passed away on November 5th, 2023 with me. I can't cope. I can't cope with the parent once. I cannot deal with them. I was extremely emotional. But to come downstairs on the morning of my birthday to see a story book, my boyfriend and maid of our life together tipped me over the edge. Can't get up, can't get up. On the last page of the book was a picture of him and one knee. Two weeks before my dad died, my boyfriend had the moment my dad alone told him his plan and My dad gave him the strongest thumbs up he'd ever given. Oh, my God.

7361178674097491246.voice_to_text: just because you can understand why someone is acting the way that they are doesn't mean that you have to tolerate it this was something I did for a really long time I would make excuses for people because I could understand that their behavior would come from insecurities and trauma and I had compassion for that and I'll likely always have compassion for that but also because of that I would tell myself that I could handle how they treated me maybe I could even show them a different way right I could help but all that did was enable their behavior and led me to sacrificing and violating my own boundaries and my own needs so just because I can understand it and tolerate it and handle it it still doesn't mean that I have to it's not my responsibility I can have that compassion without a deep connection and instead redirect that energy towards something that truly fills me up
7361178674097491246.video_description: If we were the emotional regulator within our family structure, it’s likely that we not only had to tolerate poor behavior, but soothe and balance the person giving it.  This can lead us to be deeply perceptive, and really see past the outward actions and into the inner workings of where they’re coming from.  It’s a form of compassion that formed out of necessity.  It helped us diffuse a volatile situation.  It helped survive.  But this can become a pattern that we unconsciously copy and paste onto various situations throughout the rest of our lives — relationships, friendships, work dynamics…. Situations where we actually have the autonomy to stand up for ourselves, and prioritize our own energy.  While that doesn’t necessarily mean the pattern will change overnight, it’s just an invitation to notice.  Where are you repeating this pattern, where it’s not totally needed? And how can you practice having compassion, AND boundaries? How can you maintain awareness and understanding, AND your own energy supply? Be patient. Stay open. Stay curious.  Notice how it feels 🤍 #traumahealing #healingjourney #healthyboundaries

7360361912875420971.voice_to_text: There are certain things that your employer cannot do. My name is Craig Levey and I'm an employment law attorney and here are three examples. First, your employer cannot prevent you from discussing your wages with your coworkers. The National Labor Relations Act, or NLRA, is a federal law that states that employees are allowed to discuss their wages with their coworkers, and companies cannot retaliate against employees for doing so. So if you are an employee that is covered by that law and your company has a policy that states you cannot discuss your wages with your coworkers, that is unenforceable. Second, your employer cannot terminate your employment because you complained about something illegal going on at work. For example, many employees complain about sexual harassment or discrimination at work and are retaliated against because of that. There's a federal law to protect you in that case, and also many state laws. Also, there are federal and state whistleblower laws which protect individuals if they make certain complaints that categorize them as a whistleblower. And third, your employer cannot terminate your employment because you make an OSHA complaint stating that they aren't in compliance with certain health and safety standards. Far too often I see employees make complaints with OSHA and the company responds by retaliating, often terminating the employees employment.

7356345475072527662.voice_to_text: if you were to ask everyone who the worst type of person to sit next to on a commercial flight was I think the general consensus would be a child but I would like to dispute that because I think I experienced something hundred times worse than a child I was on a flight from San Antonio to New York and it's important to note that I unfortunately had the middle seat so I was stuck between two random people before the plane took off I was hearing the two people beside me talking to each other and I quickly Learned that they knew each other so I asked if they wanted to sit next to each other both said no and in my head I was like I get it no one wants the middle seat afterwards I put my headphones on no music no podcast just noise cancellation because I was trying to fall asleep moments later I hear like a really faint singing and I just gotta check my phone to make sure I wasn't playing anything and I wasn't I take off one of my headphones and look around to see where this sound is coming from and I quickly realize that it is coming from the two people sitting next to me and the entire row in front of me harmonizing the song airplanes pretend the airplanes and the nice guy are like shooting stars I really need a wish right now while they were harmonizing one of them was recording like a Snapchat video using their selfie camera and I could see myself in their video I was just sitting there like all confused and shit the end of this Snapchat video the person holding the phone was like we're coming to you New York get ready and then in unison everyone hits they're all like and I'm still in frame just confused as after that the person sitting next to me tapped me on the shoulder and he's just like oh sorry about all that we're performing in New York and we're just really excited I was just like no you're good congrats but I really did not wanna ask any more questions because I did not wanna open up that can of worms and putting two and two together I I could figure out that I was surrounded by grown up theater kids throughout the rest of the flight they were all like whisper rehearsing and it wasn't loud but it was just enough to be like really annoying and for some reason there was all these old people sitting around us and they were just so impressed by these people like they were just eating this shit up I think that's what fueled them to continue being themselves holy shit I'm so mean like they got that out of attention and then they just went with it and everything they did was just so animated is hard to describe but like if you've ever met a theater kid you know I think the crescendo of it all was when we landed because they started singing that LA LA Land song like one of them started going like and I felt like such a negative human being because everyone around me was like oh my god that's from LA LA Land and I was just like I want to go home but this is my formal submission saying that 7355532946637475103.video_description: This New Grading Scale In #California Is Absolutely Horrifying. #biden #biden2020 #biden2024 #cali #californiacheck #grading #grades #highschool #college #trump #trump2020 #trump2024 #greenscreen
7355532946637475103.voice_to_text: Alright, so we have to talk about this. If you're unaware, this is the public school grading scale in California, and this is fucking insane. So according to the grading scale they're using today, 84 to 100 is an A, 64 to 84 is a B, 44 to 64 is a C, 24 to 44 is a D, and anything below 24% is a fail. And if this is how we're gonna grade children today, let's just fucking sell everything to China, cause we're fucked as a society. I don't know about you, but as my name says, I'm an older millennial. I was born in 83 and graduated high school in O2. When I went to school, this was my grading scale. Fact this looks like it was on fucking Parchment does not help my complex about being old. But regardless, let's look at the fucking difference. So to get an A, I needed A 95 to 100, B was 88 to 94, C was 80 to 87, D was 70 to 79. 69 and below was failing. Let's be real, that means the only people that would be passing for my time is the people who are currently getting an A. And about half the people who are getting a B. The other half of B as well as everyone else would have failed. And for me, on this scale, C is where it gets ridiculous. There are plenty of people out there in my time who were just C level students. They weren't especially smart, but they also weren't especially dumb. No, for me, see, was always just the average people. I figured that the average people were able to answer about 80% of the shit they Learned correctly. But now you can get more wrong than you do right and still have a C. You have to think that's what 44% means. That means that of all the questions you were given, you got 56% of them wrong. You got more wrong then you did right, and you're still a C student. That is fucking stupid. And D is even worse, because getting a D in California means that you got 76% of everything wrong and you're still going to graduate. You have to get 77% of everything wrong to fail. Here's the thing. I don't ever wanna work with someone who got 77% of everything wrong. I don't even wanna work with somebody who got 56% of everything wrong. Right now in California, these motherfuckers are graduating high school. This is the future generations of our society. We are gonna have a generation of people in this country who are graduating high school and college while getting 75% of everything wrong. And that is fucking horrifying.

7354826425356127520.video_description: Like it or lump it, we're in a recession and tattooing is a luxury industry, I'm seeing a lot of excuses and very few solutions being posted online. Q. What should artists be doing to ensure they survive this recession? #tattooartist #digbeth #birmingham
7354826425356127520.voice_to_text: Is this the end for tattooing? It's no secret that right now the tattoo industry is in a bad state. Artists nationally are struggling to fill their books, and when they do, they're littered with last minute cancellation. But why? Some artists have made videos claiming that it's social media suppression. Some have ranted saying that it's an over saturated market with too many tattoo artists and tattoo shops. I don't think it's either. So what can we do? Will lowering day rates and offering deals remedy this situation? Will changing the dated, industry wide outlook on how we use social media be the solution? Or do some artists need to swallow their ego and start doing small tattoos again for a much more affordable price to make sure they make ends meet? This isn't the first recession the tattoo industry is faced and it won't be the last. We have to adapt and overcome to get through this together. But the question is how? If you've agreed with what I've said or you've disagreed with what I've said, let me know in the comments. Thanks for watching. Have a sick day.

7339229220058565930.voice_to_text: I'm gonna be honest and let you in on a secret I used to be scared of Black folks and yes this also means there was a lot of anti Blackness and racism that I've had to unpack in my life over the past 30 something years and I'm gonna start out with some background not as an excuse for why I felt that way for a long time but as context so I grew up in Alabama in a time where there wasn't that much diversity in the state even less than there is now and in my elementary school it was maybe like a couple Asians and a couple Black students on my third day of kindergarten I was cornered in the bathroom by a fellow student who was Black  and she beat me up to this day I don't know why she did what she did but it doesn't really matter at the end of the day it happened and it influenced how I felt about Black people for a long time not to mention my family being Korean I grew up with a lot of harmful stereotypes about Black folks that they are good at dancing and sports and it was mostly because my family didn't know that many Black folks so these preconceived notions were all from media and things that we had seen otherwise on TV when this changed was when I entered college and yeah that was a long time to hold those views but that fear was also what kept me back from becoming closer to anyone who was Black  beyond a mere acquaintance I went to a PWI and it wasn't that much different from how I had grown up I grew up around mostly white communities and when I went to this PWI it was a sudden culture shock not because it was a largely white private little arts college but because there was suddenly a huge class divide as well in the communities of my K through 12 education most people were around the same similar income bracket even though I was always on the lower end of the scale but when I went to college and they happened to room me with one of the like other 10 Korean students I couldn't relate to my roommate at all and it's ironic because I live in California now but that's where my roommate was from and she was so different from me not just income bracket wise but I could not relate to this fellow Korean student despite what the college wanted me to do and what ended up happening was I made friends with my roommate's  college classmate for one of their classes together and Sam came over and we became really really good friends in fact Sam was my first really best friend in life and she taught me a lot and we're still in touch today we're still really really good friends today but it single handedly changed how I felt and single handedly taught me so much of what I thought was true ended up being wrong and the thing about our friendship was I don't realize we had so many commonalities because Sam is Haitian American and we ended up bonding a lot over cultural similarities and parental relationships and we would watch both western dramas like Grey's Anatomy every Thursday night and also Korean dramas and we would eat together and I went over to her house and all of these things so Sam was like my first step into decolonizing and unlearning anti Blackness and racism I also had an RA - residential adviser and his name was Petey and again like Sam Petey and I are now going on like almost 20 years of friendship because we're old and Petey was step two into unlearning all of the harmful things I had learned in my childhood and young adulthood even it's funny because you know those two friends who share one brain cell that they ping pong between each other that is basically my friendship with Petey we are not- somehow if you put us together we are intelligent individuals, separately but put together we have made some of the stupidest decisions have come up with the stupidest scenarios to be in to this day that we talk about both back when we were in school and as adults and I'm really quite thankful to those two in particular but even after that after I graduated from college and I became friends with quite a diverse group of friends and people and I think it's also partly because I'm autistic it's hard for me to relate to different people in the world and it's much easier for me to be apathetic about things which is also why my handle is goodbye apathy to remind myself that apathy is not a good thing and that yes you can be introverted but friends are the community that teach you that there is a much larger world out there and that your worldviews may be absolutely incorrect especially if you grew up with bias and inherited stereotypes and all these things drilled into you and I'm also gonna be honest and say I probably wouldn't care that much about Falasteen if I hadn't known a classmate from Falasteen also when I was in elementary school and I remember her because she was one of the very few like very very few people who was incredibly nice to me and didn't make me feel foreign and other I spoke with her recently and she sent a picture of her birthday party that I forgot I had attended but once she sent that picture I remember distinctly that no one else had invited me to their birthday party until she did and it sticks out to me as a memory that I forgot until she saw the picture and while my friend is safe while all of my friends are safe for now it's why I care about Falasteen it's why I post about anti Blackness within both the East Asian community and specifically the Korean community because it affects my friends and if that makes me selfish if that makes me weird that's fine this is how I relate to the world through my friends who I know what I've learned through my friends and I especially remember one incident from college that truly cemented how Petey and Sam go through the world and it's one Petey and I went to the library together it was late at night it was kind of chilly so Petey was in a hoodie and he had the school lanyard with his school ID around his neck and the white librarian stopped him and stopped him only and said I'm gonna need a secondary form of ID and I remember just pausing in shock like why are you asking he when he is clearly a student here and she said oh you know that lanyard could be faked it could be yours meaning me and I was like no no no no no I think I think something's wrong here I think what you're doing is very racist why would you assume that only me is the legit student when we both have backpacks we both have hoodies on we both have lanyards what is the difference between him and I our race and ethnicity and that taught me so much without Petry having to say a single word just seeing one moment in his life and it sticks with me now nearly 20 years later that this is reality for a lot of different people that I didn't give a shit about until we became friends so there's no moral of the story there's just- sharing my journey from where I began to where I'm at now and I continue to unpack things year by year I'm not done by any means but I wanted to share that because that to me means a lot more than sharing some historical figure for Black History Month that I don't know too much about this is what I know and this is what I've experienced okay bye

7255331423211605291.video_description: Whats the closest you’ve come to dying? #reddit #redditstories #redditreadings #reddit_tiktok #fyp #redditstorytime #seekhelp #minecraft
7255331423211605291.voice_to_text: Closest you've ever come to dying. On April 21st of 2017, I was in my neighborhood knocking on doors and introducing myself to the neighbors. I was 1/1 year Realtor trying to get my business going. Toward the end of a 4 hour day of door knocking, I approached the door and rang the bell. Almost immediately I felt nauseous and knew I was about to pass out. I wake up to the sound of a lady speaking to 911. She was spelling my name to the 911 operator. I always wear my name badge when out. As I came to, she asked if I wanted an ambulance. I said no, I'm just dehydrated. The lovely lady was a retired nurse in her late 60s or early 70s. She had her husband drive me the 3 blocks back home. I began drinking water but passed out a couple of more times. I called my girlfriend and asked her to come over as soon as she got off work. Not wanting to fall down again, I went to my bedroom and laid down. She arrived with Gatorade and I drank part of one before throwing it back up. I passed out a few more times. I live with my older sister who was returning from a business trip that evening. When she got home, I spoke with her about passing out multiple times. That afternoon. My sister insisted that we go to the ER. We all piled into my truck and My sister drove. I passed out again during the drive to the hospital. The ER nurse got me on a table after checking me in. By this point, I was feeling very hungry, having missed lunch, and it was now well after 10 p m. I explained to the staff that I had passed out at least 10 to 12 times today. The medical staff went into the hall to discuss my case. Impossible treatment. I felt the nausea again and told my sister it was starting again. She had not witnessed me passing out yet. She ran to the door and called the medical staff. When she turned around, my heart had flatlined. The ER staff immediately performed CPR, including shocking me with the defibrillator. When I came to, I looked at the nurse and said, it happened again, right? She asked if this is what I had been experiencing all afternoon. I confirmed it before passing out yet again. The episodes continued for the next several hours. When they finally got me awake again, the cardiologist explained that I wasn't passing out. I was actually going into cardiac arrest each time due to an issue with my vagus nerve. They decided that the best course of action would be a pacemaker. I can only imagine the pain and fear that my family went through that evening. My part was pretty easy. Heart stops, pass out, CPR and wait back up. The one benefit of dying more than 30 Times in one day is that I now have a much greater appreciation for life

7189761603955379502.voice_to_text: my mom survived a serial killer, and this is her story. okay, so my mom is attending college, and she was walking out of the library when a very handsome man with a beard approached her. it was raining really hard, and he complimented her cute polka dotted umbrella. anyways, they strike up a conversation and he mentions that because he's a photography student, he notices things like cute umbrellas. he's got an eye for it. but the university my mom is going to, they had a dress code, and beards were not allowed for students to have at that time. and so she had a little red flag like, hmm, if he's a student here, how does he have a beard? so the conversations winding down, and he offers to hold her umbrella and walk her to her car because her hands are full of books. she says that she really didn't want him to walk her. she just had this weird feeling, um, but felt awkward saying no, so she said yes. as she starts approaching her car, she said that her stomach started getting the butterflies, and it's like she just knew not to go to her car. and I think it's worth mentioning pausing the story right here because I work for a nutrition company, and I learned that your gut has 500,000,000 neurons, and your brain has one billion or a hundred billion, I don't remember. okay, I just looked it up. a hundred billion, neurons are in your brain. 500,000,000 are in your gut. and that's why they call your gut your second brain, because they are totally connected. so if you have a gut feeling, you have to listen to it. so they're walking in the parking lot, and he's asking, okay, so which car is yours? which. which direction do we walk? and my mom just can't take that feeling in her stomach anymore. she goes, oh, shoot, you know what? I just remembered I have to meet up with a friend. no need to walk me to my car anymore. I actually have to go back to the building. she then says that he acted a little bit annoyed, but he smiled and asked if he could call her later. that because it's close to finals week, he had one final project where he needed to photograph somebody and thought that she would be perfect and he would love to connect with her. my cutie mama is the biggest people pleaser you will ever meet in your entire life. maybe that's where I get it from. and she couldn't say no, but instead, she decided to come up with, like, a loop around where I just moved into my new apartment. so I don't remember the new phone number, but if you can look at my parents in the phone book, you can call them, and then we can connect. my grandma and grandpa have very unoriginal names. there's at least 10 people with the same names in the phone book. so she figured, one, he's probably not gonna spend the time looking in the phone book, and 2, she's not. he's not gonna figure out, like, which number is theirs. so my mom scurries off and thinks that she's avoided some weirdo, but, you know, didn't really think much of it until later that night.
